인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Hello, the weather is nice today.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕(安寧 peace). Literally 'Are you at peace?' Used any time of day. 안(安) appears in 안전(safety), 안심(relief).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You're leaving already? Goodbye!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕(安寧 peace) + 가다(to go). Literally 'go in peace.' Said by person staying to person leaving. 안녕히 계세요 is reverse.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'll go first. Goodbye!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕(安寧 peace) + 계시다(to stay, honorific). Said by person leaving to person staying. 안녕히 가세요 is reverse.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thank you for helping me.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 감(感 feeling) appears in 감정(emotion), 감동(moved). 사(謝 thanks) appears in 사례(thanks), 사죄(apology). Formal 'thank you.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thanks for the gift! I really like it.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean expression. More casual than 감사합니다. Past: 고마웠어요. Very casual: 고마워. Also 고맙습니다(formal polite).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm sorry for being late.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 죄(罪 crime/guilt) appears in 죄책감(guilt), 범죄(crime). 송(送 send) appears in 송신(transmission), 방송(broadcast). Very formal apology.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Oh, sorry! I didn't see you.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 미(未 not yet) + 안(安 peace). Casual 'sorry.' More formal: 미안합니다. Very casual: 미안해. Less formal than 죄송합니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Don't worry, it's okay.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean expression. Means both 'it's okay' and 'I'm fine.' Question: 괜찮아요?(Are you okay?). Formal: 괜찮습니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Yes, that's right. I think so too.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. Also used as filler word (like 'uh-huh'). Can be misheard as 내(my), so context matters. On phone: 네, 여보세요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: No, I'm not a student.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean negative. Casual: 아니. Formal: 아닙니다. Don't confuse with 아니다(to not be). Always polite to end with 요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Just a moment, I'll be right there!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 잠깐(暫間 brief moment). Native + Sino hybrid. Related: 잠깐만(wait a sec, casual), 잠시만요(more formal). Quick attention-getter.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, where is the restroom?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 실(失 lose) appears in 실수(mistake), 실패(failure). 례(禮 courtesy) appears in 예의(courtesy), 의례(ceremony). 'Excuse me' when interrupting.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: What did you say? I couldn't hear well.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 뭐(what) + 라고(quotative particle). Literally 'you said what?' Polite way to ask for repetition. Casual: 뭐라고?

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Yes, I understand. I'll do that.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 알다(to know) + -겠-(future/intention marker). Literally 'I will know' = 'I understand.' Very useful response. Formal: 알겠습니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I don't know the meaning of this word.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 모르다(to not know) + -겠-. Literally 'I won't know' = 'I don't know.' Softens the 'I don't know' by adding uncertainty.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: How do you do. Nice to meet you.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 만나다(to meet) + 반갑다(to be glad). First meeting phrase. Casual: 만나서 반가워요. Often paired with 처음 뵙겠습니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Today was fun. See you again!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. 또(again) + 만나다(to meet). Casual farewell. Also: 또 봐요(see you again), 또 보자(very casual).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: how are you? / are you doing well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's been a while! How are you?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 잘(well) + 지내다(to get along/spend time). Common greeting after not seeing someone. Response: 네, 잘 지내요(yes, I'm well).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Good morning! Did you sleep well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Not commonly used in Korean! Koreans typically just say 안녕하세요 in morning. This is Western influence. Natural: 주무셨어요?(Did you sleep well?)

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's late. Good night.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 안녕(安寧 peace) + 주무시다(to sleep, honorific). Said to elders/superiors before bed. Casual: 잘 자(sleep well). Polite: 잘 자요.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: good work / thanks for your effort
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Good work today. Get some good rest.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 수고(辛苦 hard work). Thank someone for their effort. 수(辛 hard) appears in 고생(hardship). Common at work, to service staff.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You're welcome, it's nothing.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 천만(千萬 ten million). Old-fashioned 'you're welcome.' Modern: 아니에요(no problem), 별말씀을요(don't mention it). Sounds formal/dated.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, how much is this?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. 저기(over there) + 요. Used to get stranger's attention politely. At restaurants, shops. Casual: 저기. Don't overuse.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Hello? Can you talk right now?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. ONLY used on phone, never in person. When answering: 여보세요? When checking connection: 여보세요, 들려요?(Can you hear?)

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You passed the exam? Congratulations!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 축(祝 celebration) appears in 축제(festival), 축구(soccer). 하(賀 congratulate) appears in 하례(congratulation). Casual congratulations. Formal: 축하합니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Happy birthday! I prepared a gift.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 생일(生日 birth day). 생(生 life) appears in 생활(life), 학생(student). 일(日 day) appears in 매일(every day). Happy birthday song: ♪생일 축하합니다♪

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 새해 복 많이 받으세요! 올해도 건강하세요.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Happy New Year! Stay healthy this year too.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 새해(new year) + 복(福 blessing) + 많이(a lot). Lunar New Year (설날) greeting. 복(福) appears in 행복(happiness), 복권(lottery).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Wow, this looks delicious! Thank you for the food.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. Said BEFORE eating, hands together (optional). Shows gratitude to cook/host. Casual: 잘 먹을게요. Response: 많이 드세요(eat a lot).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Thank you for the meal. It was really delicious.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. Said AFTER eating. Shows appreciation for meal. Casual: 잘 먹었어요. Response: 입에 맞았어요?(Did it suit your taste?)

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Welcome! How many people?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. 어서(quickly/welcome) + 오다(to come). Said by shopkeeper/host to customer/guest. Response: 안녕하세요. Very common in stores.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Long time no see! How have you been?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 오랜(久 long) + 만(間 interval). 'Long time no see.' Casual: 오랜만이야. Follow-up: 잘 지냈어요?(Have you been well?)

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: anything new? / nothing special going on?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 요즘 별일 없어요? 잘 지내고 있어요?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Anything new lately? Are you doing well?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 별(別 special) appears in 별로(not particularly), 별것(nothing special). 일(日/事 thing/matter). Casual 'what's up?/anything new?'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's raining a lot outside. Be careful!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 조심(操心 cautious mind). 조(操 handle) appears in 조작(manipulation). 심(心 heart) appears in 관심(interest), 마음(heart). 'Be careful.'

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: good luck / I wish you luck
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: You have an exam tomorrow? Good luck!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 행운(幸運 fortune). 행(幸 happiness) appears in 행복(happiness), 다행(fortunately). 운(運 luck) appears in 운동(exercise), 운전(driving).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: cheer up / hang in there / stay strong
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Even if it's hard, hang in there. It will work out.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 힘(力 strength) + 내다(to put out). Literally 'put out strength' = cheer up. Very common encouragement. Casual: 힘내, 화이팅!

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example: 자, 다 같이 건배! 건강을 위하여!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Alright, cheers everyone! To our health!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 건(乾 dry) appears in 건조(dry), 건강(health). 배(杯 cup) appears in 잔(cup). Toast: 건배! Informal: 위하여!(for/to!).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: It's lunchtime, have you eaten?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 식사(食事 meal). 식(食 eat) appears in 식당(restaurant), 식품(food). Common Korean greeting like '밥 먹었어요?' Polite small talk.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: I'll be back / I'm heading out
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Mom, I'm heading out to school!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 다녀오다(to go and come back). Said when leaving home/office. Response: 다녀오세요(have a good trip). 오겠습니다 = future intention.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm home! School was fun today.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 다녀오다(to go and come back). Said when returning home/office. Response: 잘 다녀왔어?(Welcome back, casual). Past tense of 다녀오겠습니다.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: The door is open. Come in!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 들어오다(to come in). Response to knock/doorbell. Host says this to guest. Casual: 들어와. Very casual: 들어와!(come in!).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: excuse me but / pardon me but
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Excuse me, but what is your name?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 실례(失禮 discourtesy) + -지만(but). Polite way to ask personal question or interrupt. 실(失) appears in 실수(mistake), 실패(failure).

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Can you help me? Of course!
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 물론(勿論 of course). 물(勿 not) + 론(論 discuss) = without question. Response to 'can you...?' Very useful affirmative.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: I'll do that / sure, I will
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: Please send it by tomorrow. Okay, I'll do that.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean. 그렇다(to be so) + -(으)ㄹ게요(future commitment). 'I'll do that.' Agreement/confirmation. Common in phone conversations.

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: if it's okay with you / if you don't mind
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: If it's okay with you, shall I help?
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: Native Korean + honorific ending. 'If it's okay with you/if you don't mind.' Polite request. Often starts question: 괜찮으시면 도와드릴까요?

인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).english: please / I ask of you / I request
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).example_en: I'm counting on you. Please help me a lot.
인사 & 기본 표현 (Greetings).notes: 부탁(付託 entrust). 부(付 attach) appears in 부부(couple), 부속(attachment). 탁(託 entrust) appears in 의탁(reliance). 'Please' when asking favor.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What is your name?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word, not from hanja. Name. Question: 이름이 뭐예요?(What's your name?). Formal: 성함이 어떻게 되세요?

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I am American.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Humble/polite form of 'I.' Always use 저 with strangers/elders. Related: 저희(we, humble), 나(I, casual). Common in formal speech.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I like coffee.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Casual form of 'I.' Use only with close friends/younger people. Related: 나도(me too), 나한테(to me). Never with elders.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: How old are you? (polite)
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. Age. Direct question 나이가 몇 살이에요? can be rude unless close. Polite: 연세가 어떻게 되세요?(for elders).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I am twenty-five years old.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Counter for age (years old). Use with native numbers: 한 살(1 year old), 두 살(2 years old). 몇 살(how old?). Related: 살다(to live).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Which country are you from?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. Country. Question: 어느 나라 사람이에요?(What country are you from?). Response: 한국 사람이에요(I'm Korean).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 한국에 온 지 일 년 됐어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: It's been one year since I came to Korea.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 한(韓 Korea) appears in 한국인(Korean person), 한국어(Korean language), 한글(Hangul). 국(國 country) appears in 중국(China), 미국(USA).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I came from America.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 미(美 beautiful/America) appears in 미인(beauty), 미술(fine art). 국(國 country). Literally 'beautiful country,' translation of 'America.'

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I like Japanese food.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 일(日 sun/Japan) appears in 일요일(Sunday), 일출(sunrise). 본(本 origin/book). 日本 literally 'sun origin,' Japan's hanja name.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I can speak a little Chinese.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 중(中 middle/center) appears in 중간(middle), 중요(important). 국(國 country). 中國 literally 'middle kingdom,' China's traditional name.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What is your job?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 직(職 job) appears in 직원(employee), 직장(workplace). 업(業 work) appears in 사업(business), 기업(enterprise). Question: 직업이 뭐예요?

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I am a university student.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 학(學 study) appears in 학교(school), 학원(academy), 과학(science). 생(生 life/person) appears in 선생님(teacher), 생일(birthday).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm an office worker. I work at an IT company.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 회사(會社 company). 회(會 meet) appears in 회의(meeting), 기회(opportunity). 사(社 organization) appears in 사회(society). 원(員 member).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Teacher, which school do you teach at?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 선생(先生 first-born). 선(先 first) appears in 선배(senior), 우선(priority). 생(生) appears in 학생(student). 님(honorific suffix).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My mother is a homemaker.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 주(主 main) appears in 주인(owner), 주요(main). 부(婦 woman/wife) appears in 부인(wife, formal). Modern: 가정주부(homemaker).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The doctor prescribed medicine for me.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 의(醫 medicine) appears in 의료(medical care), 의학(medicine). 사(師 master) appears in 교사(teacher), 변호사(lawyer). Doctor.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The nurse gave me a shot.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 간호(看護 care). 간(看 look after) appears in 간병(nursing). 호(護 protect) appears in 보호(protection). 사(師 master). Nurse.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: The chef at this restaurant is really famous.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 요리(料理 cooking). 요(料 material) appears in 재료(ingredient). 리(理 reason) appears in 관리(management). 사(師 master). Chef.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Who is your favorite singer?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 가(歌 song) appears in 가요(pop song), 노래(song). 수(手 hand/person skilled in). Singer. Related: 노래하다(to sing).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I watched the drama that actor appeared in.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. Actor/actress. Also means 'to learn' (different word, same spelling). Related: 연기하다(to act), 영화배우(movie star).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Where do you live?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean. Where. Questions: 어디에 살아요?(Where do you live?), 어디 가요?(Where are you going?). Also used as filler.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What are you doing?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean. What. 뭐 is casual/spoken form of 무엇. Related: 뭔가(something), 뭔데(what is it?). Everyday speech uses 뭐.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Who is that person?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean. Who. Question: 누구예요?(Who is it?). Possessive: 누구의(whose). Related: 누군가(someone), 누가(who, subject).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Why are you learning Korean?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean. Why. Can sound confrontational if said forcefully. Related: 왜요?(why?), 왜냐면(because). Soften with 왜요? for politeness.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: How do you do this?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean. How. Related: 어때요?(How is it?), 어떤(what kind). Essential question word. Also: 어떻게 지내요?(How are you?).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My hometown is Busan. The sea is beautiful there.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 고(故 old/past) appears in 고인(deceased), 고생(hardship). 향(鄕 village) appears in 시향(city and countryside). Question: 고향이 어디예요?

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I got married last year. I'm very happy.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 결혼(結婚 marriage). 결(結 tie) appears in 결과(result), 결론(conclusion). 혼(婚 marriage) appears in 혼례(wedding ceremony). To marry.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 저는 아직 미혼이에요. 결혼할 생각은 없어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm still single. I have no plans to get married.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 미(未 not yet) appears in 미래(future), 미완(incomplete). 혼(婚 marriage). Unmarried/single. Formal term on documents/forms.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Are you married or single?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 기(旣 already) appears in 기존(existing). 혼(婚 marriage). Married. Formal term on documents/forms. Opposite of 미혼.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What was your major in college? Mine was economics.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 전(專 specialize) appears in 전문(specialty), 전용(exclusive). 공(攻 attack/study) appears in 공부(study). Major/field of study.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I graduated from university this year.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 졸업(卒業 graduation). 졸(卒 finish) appears in 졸업생(graduate). 업(業 work) appears in 직업(job), 수업(class). To graduate.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: Do you have experience working in Korea?
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 경험(經驗 experience). 경(經 pass through) appears in 경과(progress), 경로(route). 험(驗 test) appears in 실험(experiment), 시험(test).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I have a lot of interest in Korean culture.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 관심(關心 interest). 관(關 relate) appears in 관계(relationship), 관련(related). 심(心 heart) appears in 마음(heart), 심장(heart).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 제 꿈은 한국어 선생님이 되는 거예요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My dream is to become a Korean language teacher.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: Native Korean word. Dream (both sleep & life aspiration). Related: 꿈을 꾸다(to dream), 꿈을 이루다(to achieve a dream).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My personality is on the quiet side.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 성격(性格 personality). 성(性 nature) appears in 성질(temperament), 개성(individuality). 격(格 standard) appears in 자격(qualification), 격식(formality).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 저는 외향적이라서 사람 만나는 걸 좋아해요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm extroverted, so I like meeting people.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 외향적(外向的 extroverted). 외(外 outside) appears in 외부(outside), 해외(overseas). 향(向 direction) appears in 방향(direction). Outgoing personality.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 저는 좀 내성적이에요. 혼자 있는 게 편해요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: I'm a bit introverted. I'm comfortable being alone.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 내성적(內省的 introverted). 내(內 inside) appears in 내부(inside), 국내(domestic). 성(省 reflect) appears in 반성(reflection). Reserved personality.

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example: 제 특기는 요리예요. 한식을 잘 만들어요.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My special skill is cooking. I'm good at making Korean food.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 특기(特技 special skill). 특(特 special) appears in 특별(special), 특징(characteristic). 기(技 skill) appears in 기술(technology), 기능(function).

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: What's your blood type? I'm type A.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 혈액형(血液型 blood type). 혈(血 blood) appears in 출혈(bleeding). 액(液 liquid) appears in 액체(liquid). 형(型 type). Popular topic in Korea!

자기소개 (Self-Introduction).example_en: My nickname is 'teddy bear.' My friends call me that.
자기소개 (Self-Introduction).notes: 별명(別名 nickname). 별(別 separate) appears in 특별(special), 별도(separately). 명(名 name) appears in 이름(name), 유명(famous).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: One plus one is two.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: One (1). Sino-Korean 一. Used for dates, money, phone numbers, math. Related: 일월(January), 일요일(Sunday), 일등(first place).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: February is short.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Two (2). Sino-Korean 二. Used in dates, money, math. 이월(February), 이틀(2 days, native). Also particle 'this/that.'

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please wait just three minutes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Three (3). Sino-Korean 三. 삼월(March), 삼각형(triangle), 삼겹살(pork belly, three-layered meat). Used in dates, money, math.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Cherry blossoms bloom in April.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Four (4). Sino-Korean 四, sounds like 死 (death), so 4 is unlucky. Some buildings skip 4th floor (F instead). 사월(April).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It's five thousand won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Five (5). Sino-Korean 五. Money uses Sino: 오천 원(5,000 won), 오만 원(50,000 won). 오월(May), 오후(afternoon).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It rains a lot in June.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Six (6). Sino-Korean 六. 육월(June), 육십(60). Pronunciation may shift to '뉵' in certain combinations for easier pronunciation.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Seven times eight is fifty-six.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Seven (7). Sino-Korean 七. 칠월(July), 칠십(70). Math uses Sino: 칠 더하기 삼(7+3). Lucky number in some contexts.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: August 15th is Liberation Day.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Eight (8). Sino-Korean 八, sounds like 팔(arm, native). 8 is lucky (prosperity). 팔월(August), 팔십(80). Popular in phone numbers.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: You need to memorize the multiplication table.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Nine (9). Sino-Korean 九. 구월(September), 구십(90), 구구단(multiplication table, literally 9×9 table). Highest single digit.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's meet in ten minutes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ten (10). Sino-Korean 十. Combine: 십일(11), 십이(12). 십월(October), 십분(10 minutes). Say 십 not 일십 for 10.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: This bag is 35,100 won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Hundred (100). Sino-Korean 百. Say 백 not 일백 for 100. 백일(100 days, baby celebration), 이백(200), 삼백(300).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The bus fare is 1,300 won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Thousand (1,000). Sino-Korean 千. Say 천 not 일천 for 1,000. 천 원(1,000 won), 이천(2,000). 천천히(slowly) uses same character.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: These clothes are 50,000 won.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ten thousand (10,000). Sino-Korean 萬. Korean groups by 만 not 1,000. Trickiest for English speakers. 만 원(10,000 won), 십만(100,000).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please give me just one.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: One (native Korean). Shortens to 한 before counters: 한 개(one item), 한 명(one person). Also means 'only/just one.'

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's go together, just the two of us.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Two (native Korean). Shortens to 두 before counters: 두 개, 두 명. 둘이(two people together), 둘다(both). Use with counters.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Choose one out of three.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Three (native Korean). Shortens to 세 before counters: 세 개, 세 명. 셋 중(among the three). Used for age, hours, counting items.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: We need four chairs.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Four (native Korean). Shortens to 네 before counters: 네 개, 네 명. 네 sounds like 'your' causing shifts. Age, hours, counting.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: There are five fingers.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Five (native Korean). No shortening. 다섯 개, 다섯 명. 손가락 다섯 개(five fingers). Used with counters for age, time, items.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Let's meet at six o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Six (native Korean). No shortening. 여섯 시(6 o'clock), 여섯 명(6 people). Used with counters for age, time, items.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: One week is seven days.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Seven (native Korean). No shortening. 일곱 시(7 o'clock), 일주일(7 days/week). Used with counters for age, time, items.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I go to work at eight o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Eight (native Korean). No shortening. 여덟 시(8 o'clock), 여덟 명(8 people). Used with counters for age, time, items.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: You have to come by nine o'clock.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Nine (native Korean). No shortening. 아홉 시(9 o'clock), 아홉 개(9 items). Used with counters for age, time, items.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I practiced ten times.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ten (native Korean). Combines: 열하나(11), 열둘(12), 열셋(13). 열 시(10 o'clock), 열 명(10 people). Use with counters.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I'm twenty years old this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Twenty (native Korean). 스무 before counters: 스무 살(20 years old), 스무 명(20 people). Age is most common use. Beyond 20, rare except age.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 서른 살이 되면 뭘 하고 싶어요?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: What do you want to do when you turn thirty?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Thirty (native Korean). Mainly for age: 서른 살(30 years old). Less common than Sino-Korean 삼십 in other contexts.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My father is forty-five years old.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Forty (native Korean). Mainly for age: 마흔 살(40 years old). 마흔다섯(45). Less common than Sino-Korean 사십.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandmother started exercising from age fifty.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Fifty (native Korean). Mainly for age: 쉰 살(50 years old). Beyond 50, native numbers rare except for age counting.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please give me three apples.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: General counter for items/things. Use native numbers: 한 개, 두 개, 세 개. Most versatile counter. When unsure, use 개.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The four of us eat together.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for people (polite). 명(名 name/person) appears in 이름(name), 유명(famous). Use native numbers: 한 명, 두 명. More polite than 사람.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Do you want to drink a cup of coffee?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for cups/glasses. 잔(盞). Use native numbers: 한 잔, 두 잔. 커피 한 잔(a cup of coffee), 한 잔 하다(have a drink, idiom).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I raise two cats.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for animals. Use native numbers: 한 마리, 두 마리. 고양이 두 마리(two cats), 개 한 마리(one dog). Not for people!

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please lend me a sheet of paper.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for flat items. 장(張 sheet) appears in 긴장(tension), 과장(exaggeration). 종이 한 장(one sheet), 사진 한 장(one photo). Use native numbers.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 이번 달에 책 세 권을 읽었어요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I read three books this month.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for books. 권(卷 volume) appears in 권리(right), 권위(authority). 책 한 권(one book), 잡지 두 권(two magazines). Use native numbers.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I bought a bottle of water.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for bottles. 병(甁/瓶). 물 한 병(one bottle of water), 맥주 두 병(two beers). Use native numbers. Also 병(病 disease).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: There are two cars.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for vehicles/machines. 대(臺 platform) appears in 대통령(president), 무대(stage). 차 두 대(two cars), 휴대폰 한 대(one phone). Use native numbers.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I bought a new set of clothes.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for sets of clothing. Native Korean. 옷 한 벌(one outfit/suit), 양복 한 벌(one suit). Refers to complete matching sets.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: How old are you?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for age. Native Korean, from 살다(to live). Use native numbers: 한 살, 스무 살. 몇 살이에요?(How old are you?)

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Try one more time.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for times/occurrences. 번(番 number) appears in 번호(number), 번역(translation). 한 번(once), 두 번(twice), 세 번(three times). Use native numbers.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Get off at the third floor.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Counter for floors. 층(層 layer) appears in 지층(geological layer). Sino numbers: 일 층(1st floor), 삼 층(3rd floor), 지하 일 층(B1).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I have a ten-thousand won bill.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Korean currency (won). 원(圓/元 circle/origin) appears in 원래(originally). ALWAYS use Sino numbers: 천 원(1,000₩), 만 원(10,000₩).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandmother is sixty years old this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Sixty (native Korean). Mainly for age: 예순 살(60 years old). Less common than Sino-Korean 육십 in other contexts.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Seventy people live in this village.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Seventy (native Korean). Mainly for age: 일흔 살(70 years old). Less common than Sino-Korean 칠십 in other contexts.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: My grandfather is over eighty.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Eighty (native Korean). Mainly for age: 여든 살(80 years old). Less common than Sino-Korean 팔십 in other contexts.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It's the ninety-ninth attempt.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Ninety (native Korean). Mainly for age: 아흔 살(90 years old). 아흔아홉(99). Less common than Sino-Korean 구십.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: First, health is the most important thing.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: First/firstly. Native Korean ordinal. Birth order: 첫째 아들(first son). Listing: 첫째, 건강(first, health). Related: 첫 번째(first time).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The second child starts school this year.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Second/secondly. Native Korean ordinal. Birth order: 둘째 아이(second child). Listing: 둘째, 돈(second, money). Related: 두 번째(second time).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: We finally arrived on the third day.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Third/thirdly. Native Korean ordinal. Birth order: 셋째 딸(third daughter). Listing: 셋째, 시간(third, time). Related: 세 번째(third time).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please sit in the fourth row.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Fourth/fourthly. Native Korean ordinal. Birth order: 넷째 아들(fourth son). Listing: 넷째, 건강(fourth, health). Related: 네 번째(fourth time).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Please cut the apple in half.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Half. 반(半). Also in time: 두 시 반(2:30, half past two). 반으로 자르다(cut in half). Also means 'class/group.'

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Shall we meet around three o'clock?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: About/approximately. Particle for casual approximation. 세 시쯤(around 3 o'clock), 백 개쯤(about 100 items). More casual than 약.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: We need more than ten people to gather.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: More than/above. 이(以 by/with) + 상(上 above). 열 명 이상(10 or more people). Inclusive. Opposite: 이하(below/under).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Children twelve and under are free.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Less than/below. 이(以) + 하(下 below). 열 명 이하(10 or fewer people). Inclusive. 18세 이하(18 and under).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: It takes about ten minutes from here.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Approximately/about. 약(約 promise/approximate) appears in 약속(promise), 조약(treaty). 약 십 분(about 10 min). More formal than 쯤.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 오늘 비 올 확률이 팔십 퍼센트예요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: The chance of rain today is eighty percent.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Loanword from English 'percent.' Use Sino-Korean numbers: 오십 퍼센트(50%). Native: 할(割). 백 퍼센트(100%).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example: 이 가방은 저것보다 두 배 비싸요.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: This bag is twice as expensive as that one.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Times/fold (multiples). 배(倍). 두 배(twice/double), 세 배(three times). 배로(by fold). Also 배(boat/pear/stomach, different words).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Half of the work is done.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Half (noun). 절(折 fold) appears in 절충(compromise). 반(半 half). 일의 절반(half the work). More formal than 반.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: What time do we leave?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: How many/some. Native Korean question word. 몇 시(what time?), 몇 살(how old?), 몇 개(how many items?). Also: 'a few.'

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: Is everyone ready?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: All/everyone. Native Korean. 모두 준비됐어요?(Is everyone ready?). Related: 모두 다(all together), 모든(all, modifier).

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: How much is all of this?
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: Everything/all. 전(全 whole) appears in 전체(entire), 전국(whole country). 부(部 part). 이거 전부(all of this). More formal than 모두.

숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).example_en: I'll do the rest tomorrow.
숫자 & 세기 (Numbers & Counting).notes: The rest/remainder. Native Korean. 나머지는 내일(the rest tomorrow). Math: 나머지(remainder). Opposite: 전부(everything).

가족 (Family).example_en: My family has four members.
가족 (Family).notes: 가(家 house) appears in 가정(household), 가구(furniture), 가사(housework). 족(族 clan) appears in 민족(nation), 종족(race), 족보(genealogy).

가족 (Family).example_en: My parents live in Busan.
가족 (Family).notes: 부(父 father) appears in 부권(paternal rights), 부계(paternal line). 모(母 mother) appears in 모성(motherhood), 모국어(mother tongue). 님 is honorific suffix. Say 우리 부모님 not 내 부모님.

가족 (Family).example_en: Dad made dinner for us.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Casual/affectionate for 'dad.' Formal: 아버지, most respectful: 아버님. Baby-talk origin. Common phrase: 아빠가 만든 음식(food dad made).

가족 (Family).example_en: Mom, what are you doing today?
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Casual/affectionate for 'mom.' Formal: 어머니, most respectful: 어머님. Baby-talk origin. 밥 먹었어요? 엄마가 물어봐요(Did you eat? Mom asks).

가족 (Family).example_en: My older brother goes to university.
가족 (Family).notes: 형(兄 older brother) appears in 형님(respectful brother), 형제(brothers/siblings). Used by males only to address older brother or older male friend.

가족 (Family).example_en: My older sister is good at cooking.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Used by males only to address older sister or older female friend. Also used for any older female acquaintance. Cannot be used by females.

가족 (Family).example_en: Oppa, let's go watch a movie together.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Used by females only to address older brother or older male friend/boyfriend. Very common in Korean culture. Cannot be used by males.

가족 (Family).example_en: My older sister bought me new clothes.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Used by females only to address older sister or older female friend. Essential in female relationships. Cannot be used by males.

가족 (Family).example_en: My younger brother is a high school student.
가족 (Family).notes: 남(男 male) appears in 남자(man), 남성(male gender), 남편(husband). 동생 is native Korean for younger sibling. Conjugation: 남동생이/남동생을.

가족 (Family).example_en: My younger sister is cute.
가족 (Family).notes: 여(女 female) appears in 여자(woman), 여성(female gender), 여행(travel). 동생 is native Korean for younger sibling. Related: 친동생(blood sibling), 막내(youngest).

가족 (Family).example_en: Grandfather told us a story.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Also used respectfully to address any elderly man. Related: 할머니(grandmother). Say 우리 할아버지 not 내 할아버지. Honorific: 할아버님.

가족 (Family).example_en: I go to grandmother's house often.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Also used respectfully to address any elderly woman. Affectionate term. Common: 할머니 집(grandmother's house), 할머니 손맛(grandmother's special cooking touch).

가족 (Family).example_en: My son starts elementary school this year.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Related: 첫아들(eldest son), 아들딸(children of both genders), 아들 같다(like a son). Traditional preference for sons changing in modern Korea.

가족 (Family).example_en: My daughter sings really well.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Related: 맏딸(eldest daughter), 외동딸(only daughter), 딸내미(affectionate). Modern Korea values daughters equally. Common: 딸바보(father who dotes on daughter).

가족 (Family).example_en: My husband cooks for me.
가족 (Family).notes: 남(男 male) appears in 남자(man), 남동생(younger brother). 편(便 side/companion) appears in 편리하다(convenient), 편지(letter). Formal term. Casual: refer by name or 우리 남편.

가족 (Family).example_en: I'm going on a trip with my wife.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Formal term for wife. Also say 부인(lady/wife) in formal contexts. Casual: often use indirect reference like 우리 애 엄마(mother of our child). Related: 안사람(informal, old-fashioned).

가족 (Family).example_en: The child is playing in the park.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Literally child, but not baby. Related: 아이들(children), 아이 같다(childlike), 어린아이(young child). Common: 아이가 셋이에요(I have three children).

가족 (Family).example_en: The baby is sleeping right now.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Baby specifically, younger than 아이. Related: 갓난아기(newborn), 신생아(newborn Sino-Korean). Common: 아기 울음소리(baby crying sound), 아기자기하다(cute/adorable).

가족 (Family).example_en: I bought a birthday present for my niece/nephew.
가족 (Family).notes: 조(甥 nephew/niece) appears in 조카딸(niece specifically), 조카아들(nephew specifically). Gender-neutral term. Related: 조카들(nieces and nephews). Common: 조카 바보(doting aunt/uncle).

가족 (Family).example_en: My uncle lives in Seoul.
가족 (Family).notes: 삼(叔 uncle) appears in 백숙(chicken soup, different character). 촌(村 village/relation) appears in 시골 촌(countryside). Unmarried father's younger brother traditionally. Now used broadly for uncles.

가족 (Family).example: 이모가 맛있는 음식을 많이 해 주세요.
가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal aunt makes a lot of delicious food.
가족 (Family).notes: 이(姨 aunt maternal side) + 모(母 mother) appears in 모성(motherhood), 모국(motherland). Mother's sister. Related: 외할머니(maternal grandmother), 이모부(aunt's husband). Common: 이모네 집(aunt's house).

가족 (Family).example_en: My paternal aunt lives in America.
가족 (Family).notes: 고(姑 father's sister) + 모(母 mother) appears in 모국어(mother tongue). Father's sister. Related: 고모부(aunt's husband), 큰고모(father's older sister), 작은고모(father's younger sister).

가족 (Family).example_en: My cousin is getting married next week.
가족 (Family).notes: 사(四 four) appears in 사계절(four seasons), 사각형(square). 촌(村 village/degree of relation). Literally 'four degrees of relation.' Gender-neutral. Related: 사촌형(older male cousin), 사촌언니(older female cousin).

가족 (Family).example_en: My mother-in-law made kimchi for us.
가족 (Family).notes: 시(媤 husband's family) appears in 시집(husband's family home), 시아버지(father-in-law). Native 어머니(mother). Related: 시댁(husband's family), 시집가다(marry into husband's family). Traditional relationship often challenging.

가족 (Family).example_en: My mother-in-law (wife's mom) came to visit.
가족 (Family).notes: 장(丈 wife's family) appears in 장인(father-in-law). 모(母 mother) appears in 모국(motherland). 님 honorific. Very respectful term. Related: 사위(son-in-law). Common: 장모님 생신(mother-in-law's birthday).

가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal grandfather lives in the countryside.
가족 (Family).notes: 외(外 outside/maternal) appears in 외국(foreign country), 외출(going out). Maternal grandfather. Related: 외할머니(maternal grandmother), 외갓집(maternal grandparents' house). Contrast: 할아버지(paternal grandfather).

가족 (Family).example_en: My maternal grandmother sent us kimchi.
가족 (Family).notes: 외(外 outside/maternal) appears in 외국인(foreigner), 외모(appearance). Maternal grandmother. Related: 외할아버지(maternal grandfather), 외가(maternal family). Often closer relationship than paternal in modern Korea.

가족 (Family).example_en: How many brothers/siblings do you have?
가족 (Family).notes: 형(兄 older brother) appears in 형님(respectful brother). 제(弟 younger brother) appears in 제자(disciple), 자제(son, formal). Often means siblings in general. Question: 형제가 있어요?(Do you have siblings?)

가족 (Family).example_en: I have two sisters.
가족 (Family).notes: 자(姉 older sister) appears in 자형(sister's husband). 매(妹 younger sister) appears in 매력(charm). Sisters only. Related: 형제(brothers/siblings), 자매애(sisterly love). Common: 자매처럼(like sisters).

가족 (Family).example_en: My sister-in-law (brother's wife) cooks really well.
가족 (Family).notes: 형(兄 older brother) appears in 형제(brothers). 수(媤 brother's wife). Used by males only to address older brother's wife. Must use respectfully: 형수님. Related: 올케(female speaker version).

가족 (Family).example_en: My sister-in-law is coming to visit next week.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Used by females only to address brother's wife. Related: 형수(male speaker version), 시누이(husband's sister). Important family relationship term. Respectful: 올케언니.

가족 (Family).example_en: My brother-in-law drove me to the airport.
가족 (Family).notes: 매(妹 sister) appears in 자매(sisters). 형(兄 older brother) appears in 형제(siblings). Used by males only for older sister's husband. Related: 제부(another term), 형부(older sister's husband). Respectful: 매형님.

가족 (Family).example_en: My wife's brother came back from the military.
가족 (Family).notes: 처(妻 wife) appears in 처가(wife's family), 처형(wife's older sister). 남(男 man) appears in 남자(man), 남편(husband). Wife's brother. Related: 처제(wife's younger sister), 동서(brothers-in-law to each other).

가족 (Family).example_en: My father-in-law's birthday is today.
가족 (Family).notes: 시(媤 husband's family) appears in 시어머니(mother-in-law), 시집(marriage into husband's family). Native 아버지(father). Husband's father. Related: 시댁(husband's family home). Formal relationship.

가족 (Family).example_en: I was nervous meeting my father-in-law for the first time.
가족 (Family).notes: 장(丈 wife's family) appears in 장모(wife's mother). 인(人 person) appears in 인생(life), 인간(human). Wife's father. Very formal/respectful. Full form: 장인어른. Related: 사위(son-in-law).

가족 (Family).example_en: My daughter-in-law is very kind.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean. Son's wife/daughter-in-law. Traditionally very specific role in Korean family. Related: 사위(son-in-law), 시어머니(mother-in-law from bride's view). Common: 며느리감(potential daughter-in-law candidate).

가족 (Family).example_en: Our son-in-law is a doctor.
가족 (Family).notes: 사(壻 son-in-law) is the character. Daughter's husband. Traditional saying: 사위 사랑은 장모(mother-in-law adores son-in-law). Related: 며느리(daughter-in-law), 장인(father-in-law). Common: 사윗감(potential son-in-law).

가족 (Family).example_en: My grandson starts school this year.
가족 (Family).notes: 손(孫 grandchild) appears in 손녀(granddaughter), 손주(grandchildren collectively). 자(子 son) appears in 아들(son), 자식(children). Grandson. Related: 첫손자(first grandson), traditionally very important.

가족 (Family).example_en: My granddaughter sings really well.
가족 (Family).notes: 손(孫 grandchild) appears in 손자(grandson), 손주(all grandchildren). 녀(女 female) appears in 여자(woman), 소녀(girl). Granddaughter. Modern Korea values equally. Related: 손녀딸(granddaughter affectionate).

가족 (Family).example_en: My friend has a twin brother.
가족 (Family).notes: 쌍(雙 pair/double) appears in 쌍꺼풀(double eyelid), 쌍안경(binoculars). Native 둥이 suffix. Twins. Related: 일란성 쌍둥이(identical), 이란성 쌍둥이(fraternal). Common: 쌍둥이처럼 닮았다(look alike like twins).

가족 (Family).example_en: I'm an only child so I don't have siblings.
가족 (Family).notes: 외(外 alone/only) appears in 외롭다(lonely). Native 동 (child/sibling) from 동생. Only child. Related: 외동딸(only daughter), 외동아들(only son). Increasingly common in modern Korea. Say: 저는 외동이에요(I'm an only child).

가족 (Family).example_en: The youngest is the cutest.
가족 (Family).notes: 막(末 last/end) appears in 막차(last train), 막판(final stage). Native 내. Youngest child. Special role in Korean families, often pampered. Related: 맏이(eldest). Common: 막내라서 귀여움 받아요(Get spoiled as the youngest).

가족 (Family).example_en: I have a strong sense of responsibility because I'm the eldest.
가족 (Family).notes: Native Korean with Sino root 맏(首 first/eldest). Eldest child. Heavy responsibility traditionally. Related: 막내(youngest), 맏아들(eldest son), 맏딸(eldest daughter). Common: 맏이라서 책임감이 있어요(Have responsibility as eldest).

가족 (Family).example_en: In the past, extended families lived together.
가족 (Family).notes: 대(大 big/large) appears in 대학교(university), 대통령(president). 가족(family). Extended family living together. Traditional Korean household structure. Now rare. Related: 핵가족(nuclear family). Cultural: 대가족 제도(extended family system).

가족 (Family).example_en: These days nuclear families are common.
가족 (Family).notes: 핵(核 core/nuclear) appears in 핵심(core/essence), 원자핵(atomic nucleus). 가족(family). Nuclear family (parents + children only). Modern standard in Korea. Related: 대가족(extended family). Most Korean households now 핵가족.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Have you eaten? (Did you eat rice?)
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Literally 'cooked rice' but means 'meal' broadly. 밥 먹었어요? is common greeting meaning 'Have you eaten?' Related: 밥그릇(rice bowl), 밥상(dinner table), 점심밥(lunch).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat bread in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Portuguese 'pão' via Japanese. Loanword. Related: 식빵(sliced bread), 단팥빵(sweet red bean bread), 크림빵(cream-filled bread), 빵집(bakery). Korean bakeries everywhere.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cold noodles are delicious in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean (though has hanja 麵). General noodle term. Related: 잔치국수(banquet noodles, simple soup noodles for celebrations), 국수를 삶다(boil noodles), 소면(thin wheat noodles). Cultural: 국수 먹다(attend wedding, literally 'eat noodles').

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We grill the meat and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. General meat term. Related: 고깃집(Korean BBQ restaurant), 고기 굽다(grill meat). Korean BBQ culture centers around grilling 고기 at table. Specify type: 소고기(beef), 돼지고기(pork), 닭고기(chicken).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean beef (hanwoo) is expensive.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 소(牛 cow) appears in 한우(Korean beef), 소갈비(beef ribs). Native 고기(meat). Beef. 한우(Korean beef) is premium, expensive. Related: 쇠고기(older term), 소고기국(beef soup), 불고기(marinated beef).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Samgyeopsal is pork.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 돼지(pig) + 고기(meat). Pork, most consumed meat in Korea. Related: 삼겹살(pork belly, most popular cut), 돼지갈비(pork ribs), 돈까스(pork cutlet from Japanese tonkatsu).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make fried chicken with chicken meat.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 닭(chicken) + 고기(meat). Chicken meat. Note ㄺ final consonant cluster. Related: 치킨(fried chicken), 닭갈비(spicy chicken), 닭다리(chicken leg), 통닭(whole chicken). Korean fried chicken world-famous.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Do you like fish?
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 생(生 fresh/raw) appears in 생일(birthday), 생각(thought). 선(鮮 fresh fish) appears in 신선하다(fresh). Fish as food. Contrast: 물고기(live fish). Related: 생선구이(grilled fish), 생선찌개(fish stew), 회(sashimi).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Eating lots of vegetables is good for health.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 채(菜 vegetable) appears in 잡채(mixed vegetables), 백채(napa cabbage, different character). 소(蔬 plant/vegetable). Vegetables. Standard term. Related: 야채(older/casual term), 채소를 썰다(chop vegetables). Healthy: 채소 많이 먹어요.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat fruit after meals.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 과(果 fruit) appears in 사과(apple), 과자(snacks). 일(實 fruit/substance). General fruit term. Related: 과일 가게(fruit shop), 과일 시장(fruit market). In Korea, fruit often expensive, given as gifts.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: One apple is 1,000 won.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean (not Sino-Korean despite hanja). Apple. HOMONYM: 사과하다(apologize) completely different word! Related: 사과 깎다(peel apple), 사과잼(apple jam). Korean apples large, crisp. Common gift.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat a banana in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'banana.' Loanword. Korea imports most bananas. Related: 바나나우유(banana milk, iconic Korean drink), 바나나킥(banana-flavored snack). Cultural: 바나나는 원래 하얗다(bananas are originally curved).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The strawberries are really sweet.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Strawberry. Korean strawberries famous for large size, sweetness. Related: 딸기우유(strawberry milk), 딸기잼(strawberry jam), 딸기 따러 가다(go strawberry picking). Peak season: winter/spring.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat a lot of watermelon in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 수(水 water) appears in 물(water, native reading), 수영(swimming). 박(瓠 gourd) appears in 박하(mint), 호박(pumpkin). Watermelon. Summer essential. Related: 수박 겉핥기(superficial knowledge, idiom: licking outside of watermelon).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The grapes look delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 포(葡 grape) + 도(萄 grape) are paired hanja. Grapes. Korean grapes (especially 캠벨 포도) darker, sweeter than Western varieties. Related: 포도주(wine), 포도밭(vineyard), 청포도(green grapes). Jeju and Yeongcheon regions famous.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I can't eat a meal without kimchi.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Korea's most iconic food, UNESCO recognized. Made from fermented vegetables. Related: 배추김치(napa cabbage kimchi, most common), 깍두기(radish kimchi), 김치 담그다(make kimchi). Essential at every meal.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please make soybean paste stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 된장 (fermented soybean paste) + 찌개(stew). Staple comfort food. Related: 김치찌개(kimchi stew), 순두부찌개(soft tofu stew), 찌개를 끓이다(make stew). One of most common home meals.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 소풍 갈 때 김밥을 싸 가요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We pack kimbap when we go on picnics.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 김(seaweed/nori) + 밥(rice). Korean rice roll wrapped in seaweed. NOT sushi - no vinegar. Related: 참치김밥(tuna kimbap), 김밥을 말다(roll kimbap). Common picnic food, lunch.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put red pepper paste in bibimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 비비다(to mix) + 밥(rice). Mixed rice with vegetables, meat, sauce. UNESCO recognized. Related: 돌솥비빔밥(hot stone bowl version), 전주비빔밥(Jeonju-style, most famous). Mix thoroughly before eating.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Bulgogi is sweet and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 불(fire) + 고기(meat). Marinated beef (or pork) grilled. Sweet soy-based marinade. Related: 소불고기(beef bulgogi), 돼지불고기(pork bulgogi), 불고기 양념(bulgogi marinade). One of Korea's most famous dishes abroad.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I bought tteokbokki in front of the school and ate it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 떡(rice cake) + 볶이(stir-fried). Spicy rice cakes, most popular Korean street food. Related: 국떡(soup rice cakes), 떡볶이 소스(gochujang-based sauce). Iconic snack food, often with 튀김(fried items).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Let's go eat samgyeopsal for dinner tonight.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 삼(三 three) appears in 삼촌(uncle), 삼계탕(ginseng chicken soup). 겹(層 layer) appears in 이중(double layer). Native 살(meat/flesh). Pork belly with 3 layers fat/meat. Related: 오겹살(five-layer), 목살(pork neck). Grilled at table, wrapped in lettuce.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Ramyeon comes to mind on rainy days.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Japanese 'ramen.' Loanword. Korean instant noodles, spicier than Japanese. Related: 신라면(Shin Ramyun brand), 라면 끓이다(cook ramyeon), 봉지라면(packet ramyeon). Cultural phenomenon, comfort food. Eaten during rain, late night.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I often eat cold noodles in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 냉(冷 cold) appears in 냉장고(refrigerator), 냉동(freezing). 면(麵 noodles) appears in 라면(ramyeon), 국수(noodles). Cold noodles. Two types: 물냉면(in icy broth) and 비빔냉면(spicy mixed). Summer dish, also after Korean BBQ.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We marinate the ribs in sauce and grill them.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Ribs. Can be beef (소갈비, premium) or pork (돼지갈비). Related: 양념갈비(marinated ribs), 갈비탕(rib soup), LA갈비(LA-style short ribs). Popular Korean BBQ choice.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Beer goes well with fried chicken.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'chicken.' Loanword. Korean-style fried chicken, distinct from American. Related: 치맥(fried chicken + beer combo), 양념치킨(sauced chicken), 순살치킨(boneless). Major food delivery category. Cultural phenomenon.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make dumplings on Lunar New Year.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 만(滿 full) appears in 만족(satisfaction), 충만(fullness). 두(頭 head) appears in 두통(headache), 선두(lead). Dumplings. Related: 찐만두(steamed), 군만두(fried), 만두국(dumpling soup), 만두를 빚다(make dumplings by hand).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat rice cake on holidays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Rice cake made from pounded rice. Hundreds of varieties. Related: 떡국(rice cake soup eaten on New Year's), 가래떡(long cylinder rice cakes), 떡 썰다(slice rice cakes). Important ceremonial food.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I fry an egg and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Egg. Alternate term: 계란 (鷄卵). Related: 계란말이(rolled omelette, popular banchan), 달걀프라이(fried egg), 달걀을 삶다(boil eggs). Eggs often sold by package (10개 한 판).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like soft tofu stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 두(豆 bean) appears in 콩(bean, native reading), 두유(soy milk). 부(腐 fermented/curdled) appears in 부패(rot). Tofu. Staple in Korean cooking. Related: 순두부(soft tofu), 두부김치(tofu with kimchi), 두부 같다(soft personality).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I wash the rice and cook it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Uncooked rice grains. Rice is staple of Korean diet. Related: 밥(cooked rice), 쌀밥(white rice), 쌀값(rice price, economic indicator), 현미(brown rice). Wash before cooking: 쌀을 씻다.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please put in just a little salt.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Salt, essential seasoning. Related: 천일염(sea salt), 꽃소금(fine salt), 소금기(saltiness), 소금을 뿌리다(sprinkle salt). Cultural: throwing salt to ward off evil spirits after funeral.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Do you put sugar in your coffee?
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 설(雪 snow) appears in 눈(snow, native reading), 설경(snowy scenery). 탕(糖 sugar) appears in 당뇨(diabetes), 사탕(candy). Sugar (white like snow). Related: 백설탕(white sugar), 흑설탕(brown sugar), 각설탕(sugar cubes).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I dip it in soy sauce and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 간(肝 fermentation, different from liver) + 장(醬 sauce) appears in 고추장(red pepper paste), 된장(soybean paste). Soy sauce, foundational seasoning. Related: 국간장(light soy sauce for soup), 진간장(dark soy sauce), 양조간장(brewed soy sauce).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put red pepper paste in bibimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 고추(chili pepper) + 장(醬 sauce/paste) appears in 간장(soy sauce), 된장(soybean paste). Red pepper paste. Essential condiment, sweet-spicy-fermented. Related: 고추장을 풀다(dilute gochujang), 찹쌀고추장(glutinous rice gochujang). Defines Korean cuisine's spicy character.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I make stew with soybean paste.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 된(fermented/thick) + 장(醬 paste) appears in 간장(soy sauce), 고추장(red pepper paste). Soybean paste (fermented). One of Korea's essential seasonings. Related: 된장찌개(soybean stew), 된장을 풀다(dissolve paste in broth).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Adding sesame oil to namul makes it delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 참(sesame/true) + 기름(oil). Sesame oil with nutty aroma, essential in Korean cooking. Related: 들기름(perilla oil), 참기름 향(sesame aroma). Used as finishing oil, in namul (seasoned vegetables). Do not use for frying (burns easily).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please give me a glass of water.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Water. In Korean restaurants, water is free and unlimited. Related: 물을 마시다(drink water), 물론(of course, literally 'water wheel'), 물고기(fish), 냉수(cold water). Essential hospitality: immediately serve water to guests.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I drink milk in the morning.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 우(牛 cow) appears in 소(cow, native reading), 한우(Korean beef). 유(乳 milk) appears in 유제품(dairy products), 모유(breast milk). Milk. Related: 바나나우유(banana milk), 흰우유(plain milk), 우유팩(milk carton). Delivered fresh historically.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I'd like to drink orange juice.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'juice.' Loanword. Korea has many unique juice flavors. Related: 오렌지주스(orange juice), 포도주스(grape juice), 100% 주스(100% juice vs. concentrate). Convenience stores have huge juice sections.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 한국 사람들은 커피를 정말 많이 마셔요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean people drink a lot of coffee.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Portuguese 'café' via English 'coffee.' Loanword. Korea has highest coffee consumption per capita in Asia. Related: 아메리카노(americano, most popular), 카페(café), 커피 한 잔(a cup of coffee). Café culture massive.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like green tea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 차(茶 tea) appears in 녹차(green tea), 홍차(black tea). Tea. Includes all types. Related: 보리차(barley tea, commonly served instead of water), 옥수수차(corn tea), 차를 마시다(drink tea). Traditional Korean teas less common than in past.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I want to have a glass of beer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 맥(麥 barley) appears in 보리(barley, native reading). 주(酒 alcohol) appears in 소주(soju), 술(alcohol, native reading). Beer. Korean brands: Cass, Hite, OB. Related: 생맥주(draft beer), 맥주 한 잔(one beer). Often paired with 치킨(chicken).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 소주는 한국에서 제일 인기 있는 술이에요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Soju is the most popular alcohol in Korea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 소(燒 distilled) appears in 소각(incineration). 주(酒 alcohol) appears in 맥주(beer), 술(alcohol native). Soju, Korea's national spirit. Clear, 16-20% ABV. Related: 소주잔(small shot glass), 소주 한 잔(one shot), 소맥(soju + beer bomb). Social drinking essential.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cola goes well with fried chicken.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'cola.' Loanword. Cola/Coke. Related: 펩시(Pepsi), 제로콜라(Coke Zero), 사이다(clear soda like Sprite/7-Up). Common pairing: 치킨 + 콜라. Note: 사이다 in Korea means clear lemon-lime soda, not apple cider.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Let's go eat ice cream.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'ice cream.' Loanword. Korea has unique flavors like 녹차(green tea), 붕어빵(fish-bread). Related: 아이스크림 가게(ice cream shop), 소프트콘(soft-serve cone), 빙수(shaved ice dessert). Convenience stores have huge ice cream sections.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We eat cake on birthdays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'cake.' Loanword. Korean cakes lighter, less sweet, cream-based rather than frosting. Related: 생일 케이크(birthday cake), 초콜릿 케이크(chocolate cake), 케이크를 자르다(cut cake). Cake shops everywhere, beautiful designs.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 과자를 너무 많이 먹으면 안 돼요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You shouldn't eat too many snacks.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 과(果 fruit) appears in 과일(fruit), 사과(apple). 자(子 small/seed) appears in 자식(children), 아들(son). Snacks/cookies/crackers (packaged). Related: 새우깡(shrimp crackers, iconic), 초코파이(chocolate pie), 과자 봉지(snack bag).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I boil potatoes and eat them.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Potato. 감자탕(pork bone and potato stew) is famous Korean dish. Related: 감자튀김(French fries), 감자칩(potato chips), 감자를 삶다(boil potatoes). Very common vegetable.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Please chop the carrot finely.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Likely from English 'carrot.' Loanword. Carrot. Also modern slang: 당근이지!(Of course! from 당연하지). Related: 당근 주스(carrot juice). Used in many Korean dishes as vegetable.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: When you cut onions, tears come out.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 양(洋 Western) appears in 양식(Western food), 양말(socks). Native Korean 파(green onion). Literally 'Western onion.' Related: 파(native Korean scallion), 양파를 썰다(chop onions, causes tears). Essential in Korean cooking.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean food uses a lot of garlic.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Garlic. Korea is world's top garlic consumer per capita. Related: 마늘쫑(garlic scapes), 마늘을 까다(peel garlic), 마늘 향(garlic aroma), 까만 마늘(black aged garlic). Essential in almost all Korean cooking.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The chili pepper is too spicy!
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Chili pepper. Defines Korean cuisine. Related: 고춧가루(chili powder/flakes, essential for kimchi and gochujang), 청고추(green chili), 홍고추(red chili). Spiciness level varies. 매워요!(It's spicy!)

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We wrap samgyeopsal in lettuce and eat it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Lettuce. Essential for 쌈(wrapping meat/rice in leaves), key Korean eating custom. Related: 상추 쌈(lettuce wrap), 적상추(red leaf lettuce), 상추에 싸서 먹다(eat wrapped in lettuce with ssam sauce).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I slice cucumbers thinly and make a salad.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Cucumber. Related: 오이소박이(stuffed cucumber kimchi, popular in summer), 오이무침(seasoned cucumber side dish), 오이냉국(chilled cucumber soup). Very common in Korean side dishes.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat tomatoes sprinkled with sugar.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Spanish via Latin 'tomato.' Loanword. In Korea often eaten as fruit with salt or sugar. Related: 방울토마토(cherry tomatoes), 토마토 주스(tomato juice). Less common in traditional Korean cooking.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We make kimchi with napa cabbage.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Napa cabbage. Main ingredient in 배추김치 (most common kimchi type). Related: 배추를 절이다(salt napa cabbage for kimchi-making), 배추 가격(napa cabbage price, seasonal fluctuation affects kimchi costs). Essential vegetable in Korean cuisine.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Adding mushrooms makes the broth delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Mushroom. Related: 표고버섯(shiitake), 팽이버섯(enoki), 느타리버섯(oyster mushroom), 송이버섯(pine mushroom, most expensive). 버섯을 볶다(sauté mushrooms). Used in soups, stews, sides.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean chopsticks are metal.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Chopsticks. Korean chopsticks uniquely flat and metal (vs. round wooden in China/Japan). Related: 젓가락질(chopstick technique), 젓가락으로 집다(pick up with chopsticks). Harder to use than wooden chopsticks.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You eat soup with a spoon.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Spoon. In Korea, rice is eaten with spoon (not chopsticks like in China/Japan). Related: 숟가락으로 뜨다(scoop with spoon), 밥 먹을 때 숟가락(use spoon when eating rice). Soup also eaten with spoon.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 남은 밥으로 볶음밥을 만들어요. 간단하고 맛있어요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I make fried rice with leftover rice. It's simple and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 볶음(stir-fry) + 밥(rice). Fried rice. Popular way to use leftover rice. Related: 볶다(to stir-fry), 김치볶음밥(kimchi fried rice), 새우볶음밥(shrimp fried rice). Simple, quick meal.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We always make japchae on holidays.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 잡(雜 mixed) appears in 잡지(magazine). 채(菜 vegetables) appears in 채소(vegetables), 야채(vegetables). Stir-fried glass noodles with vegetables and meat. Sweet soy-based. Related: 당면(sweet potato glass noodles). Beloved at celebrations and holidays.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: On cold days, soft tofu stew is the best.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 순(純 pure/soft) appears in 순수(pure). 두부(豆腐 tofu). Native 찌개(stew). Soft/silken tofu stew. Served bubbling hot in stone bowl. Related: 두부찌개(regular tofu stew), 계란(egg, often added raw on top). Popular spicy comfort food.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Pork goes well with kimchi stew.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean 김치(kimchi) + 찌개(stew). Kimchi stew with pork. One of most common Korean home meals. Related: 된장찌개(soybean stew), 부대찌개(army stew). Best made with 묵은지(aged/sour kimchi). Served bubbling.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: If you eat ginseng chicken soup in summer, you get energized.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 삼(參 ginseng) appears in 인삼(ginseng). 계(鷄 chicken) appears in 닭(chicken native), 계란(egg). 탕(湯 soup) appears in 갈비탕(rib soup). Ginseng chicken soup, whole young chicken stuffed with rice, jujubes, ginseng. Traditionally eaten on 복날(hottest summer days) for stamina.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: The seafood at this restaurant is really fresh.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 해(海 sea) appears in 바다(sea native), 해안(seashore). 물(物 thing) appears in 동물(animal), 식물(plant). Seafood. Related: 해물탕(seafood stew), 해물파전(seafood pancake). Korea surrounded by ocean, seafood culture strong.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I like fried shrimp. It's crispy.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Shrimp/prawn. Related: 새우튀김(fried shrimp/tempura), 새우깡(shrimp-flavored crackers, iconic Korean snack), 새우를 까다(peel shrimp). Used fresh or dried in many Korean dishes.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Stir-fried squid is spicy and delicious.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Squid. Very popular in Korean cuisine. Related: 오징어볶음(spicy stir-fried squid), 마른오징어(dried squid snack), 오징어채(shredded dried squid). Flexible, chewy texture prized. Dried squid popular drinking snack.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: We dug for clams at the beach. It was fun.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Clam/shellfish (general term). Related: 조개구이(grilled clams), 조개탕(clam soup), 바지락(Manila clams), 조개 캐다(dig for clams). Popular at beaches, seafood restaurants.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Tuna kimbap is my favorite kimbap.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 참(參 true/real) + 치(魚 fish) or native 참(real/true). Tuna. Related: 참치캔(canned tuna, pantry staple), 참치김밥(tuna kimbap, very popular), 참치회(tuna sashimi). Canned tuna very common in Korean cooking.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Salmon sashimi is very popular these days.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 연(鮭 salmon) + 어(魚 fish) appears in 물고기(fish native), 생선(fish food). Salmon. Extremely popular in modern Korea. Related: 연어회(salmon sashimi), 연어초밥(salmon sushi). Not traditional but now ubiquitous.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Peaches are sweet and delicious in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Peach. Korean peaches large, very juicy, extremely sweet. Summer fruit. Related: 복숭아잼(peach jam), 복숭아 같다(peach-like, smooth skin compliment). Expensive but beloved.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 한국 배는 크고 시원해요. 갈비 양념에도 넣어요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Korean pears are big and refreshing. You put them in galbi marinade too.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Asian pear (Korean pear). Round, crisp, juicy, unlike Western elongated pears. Related: 배 주스(pear juice, helps with hangover), 배를 갈아서(grate pear for meat marinade). Used in galbi marinade as tenderizer.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: In winter, we eat tangerines under the blanket.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 귤(橘 tangerine/mandarin). Tangerine/mandarin orange. 제주도(Jeju Island) 귤 famous. Related: 귤을 까다(peel tangerine), 귤 향(tangerine aroma). Cultural: eating tangerines under blanket while watching TV in winter.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I put lemon in water and drink it. It's refreshing.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From English 'lemon.' Loanword. Related: 레몬차(lemon tea), 레모네이드(lemonade), 레몬에이드(lemonade drink), 레몬 청(lemon extract preserve). Popular for 상쾌한(refreshing) drinks.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 망고 빙수가 여름에 정말 인기 있어요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Mango bingsu is really popular in summer.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: From Portuguese 'mango' via English. Loanword. Imported tropical fruit, popular in Korea. Related: 망고빙수(mango shaved ice dessert, huge summer trend), 망고 스무디(mango smoothie). Expensive but trendy.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Cabbage is good for digestion. I eat it often.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 양(洋 Western) appears in 양파(onion), 양식(Western food). Native Korean 배추(napa cabbage). Green/round cabbage (different from 배추). Related: 배추(napa cabbage for kimchi), 양배추 샐러드(coleslaw). Good for digestion.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: Seasoned spinach is often eaten as a side dish.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Spinach. Related: 시금치나물(seasoned spinach, one of most common Korean side dishes), 시금치를 데치다(blanch spinach). Very common banchan (side dish). Healthy, often in bibimbap.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: In Korea, they make doenjang from soybeans.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Bean/soybean. Soybeans fundamental to Korean cuisine. Related: 콩나물(bean sprouts), 두부(tofu made from soybeans), 된장(soybean paste), 간장(soy sauce). Essential Korean ingredient. Saying: 콩 심은 데 콩 난다(you reap what you sow).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I eat nuts as a snack. They're good for your health.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 견(堅 hard/firm) appears in 견고하다(solid). 과(果 fruit) appears in 과일(fruit). 류(類 category) appears in 종류(type). Nuts/tree nuts. Related: 호두(walnut), 아몬드(almond), 땅콩(peanut). Popular gift sets especially for holidays.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I mix honey in warm water and drink it.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Honey. Also slang: 꿀 같아!(That's awesome! Sweet deal!). Related: 꿀물(honey water drink), 꿀 떠서(scoop honey), 꿀잠(sweet sleep). Cultural: honey in traditional remedies, teas.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example: 볶음 요리를 할 때 식용유가 필요해요.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: You need cooking oil when making stir-fried dishes.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 식(食 food) appears in 식사(meal), 식당(restaurant). 용(用 use) appears in 사용(use), 용도(purpose). 유(油 oil) appears in 기름(oil native). Cooking oil (general term). Related: 해바라기유(sunflower oil), 올리브유(olive oil), 기름 두르다(coat pan with oil).

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: If you add pepper to the soup, it's tastier.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: 후(胡 foreign/barbarian) appears in 호두(walnut). 추(椒 pepper) appears in 고추(chili pepper). Black pepper (different from 고추 chili pepper). Related: 후춧가루(ground pepper), 흰후추(white pepper). Used in soups, stews.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: I chop the green onion finely and put it in the soup.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Green onion/scallion. Essential Korean cooking ingredient. Related: 파를 송송 썬다(chop green onions finely, onomatopoeia), 대파(large scallion), 쪽파(small scallion). Used as garnish in almost every soup, stew.

음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).example_en: When I catch a cold, I drink ginger tea.
음식 & 음료 (Food & Drinks).notes: Native Korean. Ginger. Used in cooking and traditional remedies. Related: 생강차(ginger tea for colds), 생강을 썬다(slice ginger), 생강 향(ginger aroma). Essential in 삼계탕, marinades. 생강차 helps with colds.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Is there a good restaurant near here?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 식(食 food) appears in 식사(meal), 음식(food), 식품(groceries). 당(堂 hall) appears in 성당(cathedral), 강당(auditorium), 회당(synagogue).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll take a look at the menu.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from French 'menu.' Common phrases: 메뉴판(menu board), 세트 메뉴(set meal), 메뉴를 보다(look at menu).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please give me the menu.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 메뉴(menu, loanword) + 판(板 board). 판 appears in 칠판(blackboard), 간판(signboard), 게시판(bulletin board).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please take our order.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 주(注 pour/focus) appears in 주의(caution), 주목(attention), 주입(injection). 문(文 writing) appears in 문화(culture), 문장(sentence), 문제(problem). At restaurants: 주문할게요.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll order. One bibimbap, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Common restaurant phrase. 주문(注文 order) + -하다(do) + -ㄹ게요(I will). Essential for ordering.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Excuse me! Can we get more water, please?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. Calling phrase to get waiter's attention. More polite than just yelling. Also: 저기요 (when farther away).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Excuse me, water please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Common restaurant phrase. 물(water) + 좀(please softener) + 주세요(give me). Used for requesting water or refills.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이거 주세요. 그리고 콜라도 하나 주세요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This, please. And one cola too, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Essential ordering phrase. 이거(this thing) + 주세요(please give me). Point at menu and say this.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 여기 뭐가 맛있어요? 처음 와 봤어요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What's good here? It's my first time visiting.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Common restaurant question asking for recommendations. 뭐(what) + 맛있다(delicious). Useful for first-time visits.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: What's the recommended menu item?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 추(推 push) appears in 추진(promotion), 추가(addition). 천(薦 recommend) appears in 천거(recommendation). Ask: 추천 메뉴가 뭐예요?

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이거 매워요? 저는 매운 거 잘 못 먹어요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Is this spicy? I can't handle spicy food well.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. 맵다(spicy) conjugates: 매워요, 매웠어요. Important question since Korean food is often spicy. Related: 안 맵게(not spicy), 덜 맵게(less spicy).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 덜 맵게 해 주세요. 아이가 먹을 거예요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please make it less spicy. A child will be eating it.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Useful request phrase. 덜(less) + 맵게(spicy-ly) + 해 주세요(please make). Most restaurants can adjust spice level.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please eat a lot! (Enjoy your meal!)
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean adverb. Used to say 'Bon appétit': 많이 드세요. Also: 많이 먹다(eat a lot), 많이 마시다(drink a lot).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 조금만 주세요. 배가 별로 안 고파요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Just give me a little. I'm not that hungry.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. 조금 vs 좀: both mean 'a little,' but 좀 is shorter/casual. Pattern: 조금만(just a little).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please give me more rice.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. Common in dining: 반찬 더(more side dishes), 물 더(more water). Refills often free in Korean restaurants.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I get it to go?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 포(包 wrap) appears in 포장지(wrapping paper), 포대(sack). 장(裝 pack) appears in 위장(stomach), 가장(pretense). Ask: 포장 돼요? or 포장해 주세요.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Please pack up the leftovers.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Common phrase for takeout or boxing leftovers. 포장하다(to pack) + -해 주세요(please do). Very common in Korea.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The check, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 계(計 count) appears in 계획(plan), 합계(total), 계좌(account). 산(算 calculate) appears in 암산(mental math), 계산기(calculator). Say: 계산해 주세요 or 계산서 주세요.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Can I see the bill?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 계산(計算 calculation) + 서(書 document). 서 appears in 서류(documents), 증명서(certificate), 신청서(application form).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll pay by card.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Loanword from English 'card.' Very common in Korea. Say: 카드로 할게요(I'll pay by card). Related: 신용카드, 체크카드.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'll pay in cash.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 현(現 present) appears in 현재(present time), 현대(modern times), 현장(scene). 금(金 gold/money) appears in 금액(amount), 요금(fee), 돈(money). Say: 현금으로 할게요.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I need a receipt.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 영(領 receive) appears in 영토(territory), 영역(domain). 수(受 accept) appears in 접수(reception), 수령(receipt). 증(證 proof) appears in 증명서(certificate), 보증(guarantee).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This kimchi stew is really delicious!
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. 맛(taste) + 있다(exist) = has taste. Opposite: 맛없다(not tasty). Conjugates: 맛있어요, 맛있었어요, 맛있겠어요.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The food here is a bit not tasty.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. 맛(taste) + 없다(not exist) = no taste. Opposite: 맛있다. Less harsh alternatives: 별로예요(so-so), 그냥 그래요(just okay).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This is too spicy! Water, please.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 맵다 → 매워요, 매웠어요. Korean spice levels can be intense for beginners. Related: 안 맵다(not spicy), 매운맛(spicy flavor).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This dessert is really sweet.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. Conjugates: 달아요, 달았어요. Related: 달콤하다(sweet and pleasant), 단맛(sweet taste). Korean desserts tend to be less sweet than Western ones.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 국이 좀 짜요. 물 좀 넣어 주세요.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: The soup is a bit salty. Please add some water.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. Conjugates: 짜요, 짰어요. Related: 간이 세다(too salty/strong seasoning), 싱겁다(bland, opposite of salty).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This coffee is a bit bitter.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. Has multiple meanings: 쓰다(write), 쓰다(use), 쓰다(bitter). Context determines meaning. Conjugates: 써요, 썼어요.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example: 이 김치 좀 셔요. 오래된 거예요?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: This kimchi is a bit sour. Is it old?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 시다 → 셔요, 셨어요. Mature kimchi is deliberately sour (김치찌개 uses it). Fresh kimchi is less sour.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I ate too much so I'm stuffed.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. 배(stomach/belly) + 부르다(full). ㅡ irregular: 배부르다 → 배불러요. Opposite: 배고프다(hungry). Say: 배불러요 after meal.

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: They say the wait is thirty minutes.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 대(待 wait) appears in 기대(expectation), 대기실(waiting room), 초대(invitation). 기(期 period) appears in 기간(period), 시기(timing), 연기(postponement).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Are there any seats available?
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: Native Korean. Common phrases: 자리가 있다/없다(seats available/not), 자리를 잡다(get a seat), 창가 자리(window seat), 안쪽 자리(inner seat).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: I'd like to sit at a window seat.
식당에서 (At a Restaurant).notes: 창(窓 window) appears in 창문(window), 유리창(glass window). 가(邊 edge) appears in 길가(roadside), 강가(riverside). 자리(seat, native Korean).

식당에서 (At a Restaurant).example_en: Non-smoking section, please.
