교통 (Transportation).example_en: Where is the entrance?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 입구(入口 entrance) - 입(入 enter) appears in 입국(enter country), 입장(admission). 구(口 mouth/opening) appears in 출구(exit), 인구(population).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I'll get off at the next stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 정류장(停留場 stop) - 정(停 stop) appears in 정지(stop), 주차(parking-different 주). 류(留 remain) appears in 유류(oil/fuel). 장(場 place).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Let's meet at Seoul Station.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 역(驛 station) appears in 서울역(Seoul Station), 지하철역(subway station). Also means 'reverse' or 'role' in different contexts.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How long does it take to get to Incheon Airport?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 공항(空港 airport) - 공(空 sky/air) appears in 공기(air), 공중(aerial). 항(港 port) appears in 항구(harbor), 인천공항(Incheon Airport).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Did you check the bus schedule?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 시간표(時間表 timetable) - 시간(time). 표(表 table/chart) appears in 표시(display), 대표(representative). 버스 시간표(bus schedule).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Just go straight along this road.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Native Korean. 길을 잃다(get lost), 길이 막히다(road is blocked). Common: 길가(roadside), 길거리(street). Also means 'long.'

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Traffic in Seoul is complicated.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 교통(交通 traffic/transport) - 교(交 exchange/cross) appears in 교류(exchange), 외교(diplomacy). 통(通 pass through) appears in 통행(passage), 소통(communication).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: If the traffic light is red, you have to stop.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 신호등(信號燈 traffic light) - 신호(signal), 등(燈 light) appears in 전등(light), 등불(lamp). 빨간불(red light), 파란불(green light).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: During holidays, the highway is really congested.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 고속도로(高速道路 highway) - 고속(high speed), 도로(道路 road) appears in 길(native road). Tolled expressways connecting cities.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I passed through the toll gate with Hi-Pass.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'toll gate.' 하이패스(Hi-Pass) automatic payment system. 통행료(toll fee).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Pedestrians can cross first.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 보행자(步行者 pedestrian) - 보행(步行 walking) appears in 도보(walking). 자(者 person) appears in 운전자(driver), 소비자(consumer). 횡단보도(crosswalk).

교통 (Transportation).example: 여기서는 속도를 줄여야 해요. 학교 앞이에요.
교통 (Transportation).example_en: You need to reduce speed here. It's in front of a school.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 속도(速度 speed) - 속(速 fast) appears in 고속(high speed), 신속(quick). 도(度 degree/extent) appears in 온도(temperature), 각도(angle).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: There was a traffic accident, so the road is blocked.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 사고(事故 accident) appears in 교통사고(traffic accident), 차 사고(car accident). Different from 사고(思考 thinking). 사고가 나다(accident occurs).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: During rush hour, the traffic congestion is severe.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 교통체증(交通滯症 traffic jam) - 체증(stagnation). 체(滯 stagnant) appears in 정체(stagnation). Common during 출퇴근 시간(rush hour).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please turn on the GPS. I don't know the way.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'navigation.' Short form: 내비. Brands: 티맵(T-map), 카카오내비(Kakao Navi). Alternative: GPS.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: When you get in the car, always put on your seatbelt.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 안전벨트(安全belt) - 안전(safety). Loanword 'belt.' 안전벨트를 매다(fasten seatbelt). Required by law in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: To get a driver's license, you have to take a test.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 면허증(免許證 license) - 면허(license), 증(證 certificate) appears in 증명서(certificate), 학생증(student ID). 운전면허증(driver's license).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: A rental car is convenient on Jeju Island.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'rental car.' Also: 렌트카. 렌터카를 빌리다(rent a car). Popular on Jeju Island.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Public transportation in Seoul is very convenient.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 대중교통(大衆交通 public transport) - 대중(大衆 masses) appears in 대중문화(pop culture). Very efficient in Seoul and major cities.

교통 (Transportation).example: 첫차가 몇 시에 있어요? 일찍 가야 해요.
교통 (Transportation).example_en: What time is the first train? I need to go early.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Native Korean 첫(first) + 차(車 vehicle). 첫차 시간(first train/bus time). Opposite: 막차(last train/bus).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I missed the last train. I have to take a taxi.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Native Korean 막(last/final) + 차(車 vehicle). 막차를 놓치다(miss last train). Important to check schedule.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: You need to transfer from Line 2 to Line 3.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 환승(換乘 transfer) - 환(換 exchange) appears in 교환(exchange), 환불(refund). 승(乘 ride) appears in 탑승(boarding), 승객(passenger).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: The road was gridlocked, so it took a whole hour.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 정체(停滯 stagnation) - 정(停 stop) appears in 정지(stop). 체(滯 stagnate) appears in 체증(congestion). 정체되다(be stagnant/gridlocked).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please move to the right lane.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 차선(車線 lane) - 차(車 vehicle) appears in 자동차(car). 선(線 line) appears in 노선(route), 직선(straight line). 차선 변경(lane change).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: If you speed, you have to pay a fine.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 과속(過速 speeding) - 과(過 exceed) appears in 과도(excessive), 과정(process). 속(速 speed) appears in 고속(high speed). 과속 딱지(speeding ticket).

교통 (Transportation).english: running a red light; traffic signal violation
교통 (Transportation).example_en: I got a ticket for running a red light.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 신호 위반(信號違反 signal violation) - 위반(違反 violate) appears in 법규 위반(law violation). 신호등 무시(ignoring traffic light).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: How much is the parking violation fine?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 벌금(罰金 fine) - 벌(罰 punish) appears in 처벌(punishment), 벌점(penalty points). 금(金 money) appears in 현금(cash). 벌금을 내다(pay fine).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: You should absolutely never drink and drive.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 음주운전(飮酒運轉 drunk driving) - 음주(飮酒 drinking alcohol). Illegal and heavily punished in Korea. 음주 단속(drunk driving crackdown).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I need to renew my car insurance.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 보험(保險 insurance) - 보(保 protect) appears in 보호(protection), 보관(storage). 험(險 danger) appears in 위험(danger), 모험(adventure).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: I'm going to get a car wash this weekend.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 세차(洗車 car wash) - 세(洗 wash) appears in 세탁(laundry), 세면(washing face). 차(車 vehicle) appears in 자동차(car). 셀프 세차(self car wash).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please check the tire pressure.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'tire.' 타이어 펑크(flat tire), 타이어 교체(tire replacement), 공기압(air pressure).

교통 (Transportation).example: 기름이 거의 없어요, 주유소에 가야 해요.
교통 (Transportation).example_en: We're almost out of gas, we need to go to a gas station.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Native Korean. Means oil/fuel. 기름을 넣다(fill up gas), 식용유(cooking oil), 참기름(sesame oil). Context determines meaning.

교통 (Transportation).english: to refuel; to fill up gas
교통 (Transportation).example_en: Can I refuel here?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 주유(注油 refuel) - 주(注 pour) appears in 주입(inject), 주사(injection). 유(油 oil) appears in 기름(oil-native), 식용유(cooking oil).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: This car needs diesel.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 경유(輕油 diesel) - 경(輕 light) appears in 경제(economy). 유(油 oil) appears in 석유(petroleum), 휘발유(gasoline). Type of fuel.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Where is the electric car charging station?
교통 (Transportation).notes: 전기차(電氣車 electric car) - 전기(電氣 electricity) appears in 전기세(electricity bill). 차(車 vehicle). Growing popularity in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Self-driving technology is advancing rapidly.
교통 (Transportation).notes: 자율주행(自律走行 self-driving) - 자율(自律 autonomy), 주행(走行 driving/traveling). Future technology, tested in Korea.

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Please enter the address into the GPS.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Shortened from 내비게이션(navigation). Colloquial. 내비를 켜다(turn on GPS), 내비를 따라가다(follow GPS directions).

교통 (Transportation).example_en: Let's check the dashcam footage.
교통 (Transportation).notes: Loanword from English 'black box.' Dashcam, almost universal in Korean cars. Used for accident evidence and insurance claims.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What is your hobby?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 취미(趣味 hobby) - 취(趣 interest) appears in 취향(taste/preference). 미(味 taste) appears in 맛(taste-native), 흥미(interest). Common question: 취미가 뭐예요?

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Do you want to go see a movie this weekend?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 영화(映畫 movie) - 영(映 reflect) appears in 반영(reflection). 화(畫 picture) appears in 그림(picture-native), 만화(comics). 영화관(cinema).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I like listening to music.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 음악(音樂 music) - 음(音 sound) appears in 소음(noise), 발음(pronunciation). 악(樂 music) appears in 악기(instrument), 국악(traditional Korean music).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This song is really good!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 노래하다(to sing), 노래방(karaoke), 노래를 부르다(sing a song). Popular social activity in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to learn to dance.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 춤(dance) + 추다(to dance). 춤을 추다(dance), 춤꾼(dancer). K-pop has made dance culture very popular.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What kind of exercise/sport do you like?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 운동(運動 exercise/sport) - 운(運 move) appears in 운전(driving), 운반(transport). 동(動 move) appears in 활동(activity), 자동(automatic).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play soccer with friends.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 축구(蹴球 soccer) - 축(蹴 kick) appears in 축하(celebration-different character). 구(球 ball) appears in 야구(baseball), 농구(basketball). Very popular in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Shall we go watch a baseball game?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 야구(野球 baseball) - 야(野 field) appears in 야외(outdoors), 시야(view). 구(球 ball) appears in 축구(soccer), 농구(basketball). Korean baseball league is popular.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I often play basketball at school.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 농구(籠球 basketball) - 농(籠 basket). 구(球 ball) appears in 축구(soccer), 야구(baseball). 농구를 하다(play basketball).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go to the sea to swim in summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 수영(水泳 swimming) - 수(水 water) appears in 수족관(aquarium), 수도(waterworks). 영(泳 swim) appears in 배영(backstroke), 평영(breaststroke).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I run every morning.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 달리다(to run) + 기(nominalizer). 마라톤(marathon), 단거리(short distance), 장거리(long distance). 달리기 선수(runner).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going hiking this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 등산(登山 hiking) - 등(登 climb) appears in 등반(climbing), 등록(registration). 산(山 mountain) appears in 산책(walk-different). Very popular Korean weekend activity.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I do yoga to relieve stress.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from Sanskrit via English 'yoga.' 요가 수업(yoga class), 요가 매트(yoga mat). Popular for flexibility and stress relief.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going on a trip to Japan next month.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 여행(旅行 travel) - 여(旅 journey) appears in 여권(passport), 여객(passenger). 행(行 go) appears in 비행기(airplane), 은행(bank).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Could you take a photo for me?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 사진(寫眞 photo) - 사(寫 copy/write) appears in 묘사(description). 진(眞 truth/real) appears in 진짜(real), 진실(truth). 사진 찍다(take photo).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to learn Korean cooking.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 요리(料理 cooking) - 요(料 material) appears in 자료(data), 요금(fee). 리(理 reason/logic) appears in 이유(reason), 관리(management). 한식 요리(Korean cooking).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My younger sibling draws well.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 그림을 그리다(draw picture), 그림책(picture book). Artists: 화가(painter). Museums showcase 명화(masterpieces).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play online games with friends.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'game.' 온라인 게임(online game), 보드게임(board game). Korea has strong gaming culture, PC방(PC bang).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I take a walk in the park in the evening.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 산책(散策 walk) - 산(散 scatter) appears in 분산(distribution). 책(策 plan) appears in 대책(countermeasure). 산책하다(take a walk).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Reading is the best hobby.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 독서(讀書 reading) - 독(讀 read) appears in 음독(reading aloud). 서(書 book) appears in 도서관(library), 서점(bookstore). Popular hobby.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I went shopping in Myeongdong.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'shopping.' 쇼핑몰(shopping mall), 온라인 쇼핑(online shopping). 명동, 강남 are popular shopping areas.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My father likes fishing.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 낚시하다(to fish), 낚싯대(fishing rod), 낚시터(fishing spot). Popular relaxation activity for older men.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going camping this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'camping.' 캠핑장(campground), 글램핑(glamping). Popular family weekend activity in Korea.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: After the work dinner, we go to karaoke.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 노래(song-native) + 방(房 room). Korean karaoke in private rooms. Essential social activity, different from Western karaoke bars.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Are there any interesting dramas these days?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'drama.' K-dramas are internationally famous. 주말 드라마(weekend drama), 일일 드라마(daily drama).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I watch TV in the evening.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English. Short: TV, long: 텔레비전. TV를 보다(watch TV). Cable and streaming are very popular.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: The internet in Korea is really fast.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'internet.' Korea has world's fastest internet. 인터넷 서핑(internet surfing), 와이파이(WiFi).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: What is your cell phone number?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'hand phone.' Also: 휴대폰(mobile phone), 스마트폰(smartphone). Nearly universal smartphone ownership.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This book is really interesting.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 책(冊 book) appears in 책방(bookstore), 책상(desk), 교과서(textbook). 책을 읽다(read book). Many 24-hour bookstores.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: My father reads the newspaper every morning.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 신문(新聞 newspaper) - 신(新 new) appears in 신상품(new product). 문(聞 hear/news) appears in 소문(rumor), 견문(knowledge).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to a concert next week!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'concert.' K-pop concerts are huge. 티켓팅(ticketing) is competitive. 공연장(concert hall).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to see a musical performance.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 공연(公演 performance) - 공(公 public) appears in 공개(public release). 연(演 perform) appears in 연기(acting), 연극(theater play).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Let's go to the art exhibition together.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 전시회(展示會 exhibition) - 전시(展示 display), 회(會 meeting/event). 미술 전시회(art exhibition), 박람회(expo).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Have you been to the National Museum?
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 박물관(博物館 museum) - 박물(博物 wide learning), 관(館 building) appears in 미술관(art museum), 도서관(library). 국립중앙박물관 is major museum.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: This art gallery has many famous paintings.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 미술관(美術館 art museum) - 미술(美術 art), 관(館 building) appears in 박물관(museum). Features 전시회(exhibitions), 특별전(special exhibitions).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I learned piano when I was young.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from Italian 'piano.' 피아노를 치다(play piano). Many Korean children learn piano from young age.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm learning to play guitar.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from Spanish 'guitarra.' 기타를 치다(play guitar), 어쿠스틱 기타(acoustic guitar), 일렉 기타(electric guitar).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I always sing when I shower.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 노래(song) + 하다(do). 노래를 부르다(sing song) is more common. 노래를 잘하다(sing well).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I like drawing landscapes.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 그림을 그리다(draw picture). Related: 화가(painter), 미술(art). Irregular: 그려요, 그렸어요.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I take lots of photos when I travel.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 사진을 찍다(take photo). Also means 'stamp/mark.' 셀카(selfie), 인증샷(proof shot) are popular.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example: 주말에 친구들이랑 볼링 치러 갈 거예요.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to go bowling with friends this weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'bowling.' 볼링을 치다(play bowling-literally 'hit'), 볼링장(bowling alley). Popular date and group activity.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: In winter, we go to Gangwon-do to ski.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'ski.' 스키를 타다(ski). 스키장(ski resort) - 강원도 has popular resorts. Winter sport.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: In winter, I ice skate at the ice rink.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'skate.' 스케이트를 타다(ice skate), 아이스링크(ice rink). Popular in winter.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Surfing in Yangyang is popular these days.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'surfing.' 양양, 부산 are popular surf spots. Growing popularity among young Koreans.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go to the gym and work out every day.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'health' but means gym/fitness. 헬스장(gym), 헬스를 하다(work out). Very popular in cities.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I started pilates. My posture has improved.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'pilates.' Popular among women for core strength and flexibility. More expensive than 헬스(gym).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I made a scarf by knitting in winter.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Native Korean. 뜨개질하다(to knit). Traditional hobby. 스웨터(sweater), 목도리(scarf), 장갑(gloves) can be made.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example: 원예를 시작했어요. 꽃을 키우는 게 재미있어요.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I started gardening. Growing flowers is fun.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 원예(園藝 gardening) - 원(園 garden) appears in 공원(park), 동물원(zoo). 예(藝 art) appears in 예술(art), 기예(skill).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: On rainy days, we play board games.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword 'board game.' Popular at cafés called 보드게임 카페. Social activity, especially on rainy days.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I completed a 1000-piece puzzle!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'puzzle.' 직소 퍼즐(jigsaw puzzle). Relaxing solo activity, popular among all ages.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I follow along while watching cooking YouTube.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'YouTube.' 유튜버(YouTuber) is aspirational career. 구독(subscribe), 좋아요(like) are common terms.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I listen to podcasts during my commute.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'podcast.' Growing medium in Korea. Topics range from comedy to education.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I read webtoons during lunchtime. They're fun.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Korean innovation: web(웹) + cartoon(툰). Vertical scrolling comics for smartphones. Platforms: 네이버, 카카오. Many adapted to dramas.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I read a lot of comics when I was young.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 만화(漫畫 comics) - 만(漫 random/informal) appears in 만화책(comic book). 화(畫 picture) appears in 영화(movie), 그림(picture-native).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I volunteer every weekend. It's rewarding.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 자원봉사(自願奉仕 volunteering) - 자원(自願 voluntary), 봉사(奉仕 service) appears in 봉사활동(volunteer activity). Valued for college applications.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play badminton with friends every weekend.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'badminton.' 배드민턴을 치다(play badminton). Popular recreational sport in parks.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play table tennis at the office during lunch.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: 탁구(卓球 table tennis) - 탁(卓 table) appears in 식탁(dining table). 구(球 ball) appears in 축구(soccer). Also called 핑퐁(ping pong).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I recently started learning golf.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'golf.' 골프를 치다(play golf). Expensive hobby, popular among businesspeople and retirees.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I play tennis twice a week.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'tennis.' 테니스를 치다(play tennis), 테니스장(tennis court). Growing popularity as recreational sport.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I want to try running a marathon next year.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'marathon.' 서울 국제 마라톤 is famous. 하프 마라톤(half marathon), 풀 코스(full course).

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I tried riding a yacht in Jeju.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'yacht.' 요트를 타다(ride yacht). Luxury activity, available on Jeju and coastal areas.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I'm going to get my diving certification this summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'diving.' 스쿠버 다이빙(scuba diving). Popular in tropical vacations, requires certification.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I can't do bungee jumping because it's scary.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'bungee jumping.' Extreme sport. Popular spots in Korea include Nami Island area.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: I go rafting with friends in the summer.
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'rafting.' Popular in 강원도 rivers during summer. Group adventure activity.

취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).example_en: Riding the zipline was such a thrill!
취미 & 여가 (Hobbies & Leisure).notes: Loanword from English 'zipline.' Adventure activity growing in Korean mountain resorts and theme parks.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm really happy because I passed the exam.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean adjective. ㅡ irregular: 기뻐요(polite), 기뻤어요(past). Noun form: 기쁨(joy, delight). Common collocations: 기쁜 소식(happy news), 기쁜 마음(glad heart). Compare: 행복하다 is general happiness, while 기쁘다 is happiness tied to a specific event or reason.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm happy when I'm with my family.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 행(幸 fortune) appears in 불행(misfortune), 다행(fortunately), 행운(luck). 복(福 blessing) appears in 축복(blessing), 복권(lottery ticket). Polite: 행복해요. General, lasting happiness as opposed to event-specific 기쁘다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This movie is so sad.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 슬퍼요(polite), 슬펐어요(past). Noun form: 슬픔(sadness). Common: 슬픈 영화(sad movie), 슬픈 노래(sad song). Often paired with 너무 for emphasis: 너무 슬퍼요.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 친구가 약속을 안 지켜서 화가 나요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm angry because my friend didn't keep the promise.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: 화(火 fire) is also used as 'anger.' 화가 나다(anger rises, state) vs 화를 내다(to express anger at someone, action). Polite: 화나요. Related emotions: 짜증나다(annoyed, milder), 열받다(ticked off, slang). Common: 화가 많이 났어요(I was very angry).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: It's scary to walk alone at night.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 무서워요(polite), 무서웠어요(past). Modifier: 무서운. Common: 무서운 영화(scary movie), 무서운 이야기(scary story). 무섭다 describes the scary thing itself; 겁나다 or 두렵다 describe the person who feels fear.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was surprised because there was a sudden loud sound.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 놀라요. Past: 놀랐어요 (very commonly used). 깜짝 놀라다(to be startled/shocked). Related adjective: 놀랍다(amazing, surprising). Common: 깜짝 선물(surprise gift). Often used in past tense: 깜짝 놀랐어요!

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I sometimes feel lonely because I live alone.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 외로워요(polite), 외로웠어요(past). Noun form: 외로움(loneliness). Modifier: 외로운. Common: 외로운 밤(lonely night), 혼자라서 외롭다(lonely because I'm alone). Related: 쓸쓸하다(desolate, more poetic).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm bored because I have nothing to do.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 심심해요. Casual everyday boredom from having nothing to do. Compare: 지루하다 is boredom from tedious content (boring movie), while 심심하다 is idle boredom. Common: 심심할 때(when bored), 심심하면 연락해(text me if you're bored).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm worried because I have an interview tomorrow.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean compound. 걱정(worry) + 되다(to become). Polite: 걱정돼요. 걱정되다(to be worried, involuntary feeling) vs 걱정하다(to worry, active). Common: 걱정하지 마세요(don't worry), 걱정이 많다(to worry a lot). Noun: 걱정(worry).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I always get nervous before presentations.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 긴(緊 tight) + 장(張 stretch) = tension. Polite: 긴장돼요. 긴장되다(to feel nervous) vs 긴장하다(to tense up actively). Common: 긴장을 풀다(to relax), 긴장감(suspense/tension). Often before presentations or exams.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel embarrassed singing in front of people.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 부끄러워요(polite), 부끄러웠어요(past). Noun: 부끄러움(shyness/embarrassment). Covers both social shyness and momentary embarrassment. Common: 부끄러운 경험(embarrassing experience). Related: 창피하다(ashamed), 쑥스럽다(bashful).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm proud because my son studies hard.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 자랑스러워요(polite), 자랑스러웠어요(past). From 자랑(boast/pride) + 스럽다(having quality of). 자랑하다(to brag/boast). Common: 자랑스러운 순간(proud moment), 부모님이 자랑스러워요(I'm proud of my parents).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was touched after hearing that story.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 감(感 feel) appears in 감사(thanks), 감각(sense), 감정(emotion). 동(動 move) appears in 운동(exercise), 행동(action), 동작(movement). Polite: 감동해요. 감동적이다(touching/moving). Common: 감동적인 영화(moving film).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was a bit disappointed after seeing the results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 실(失 lose) appears in 실수(mistake), 실패(failure). 망(望 hope/gaze) appears in 희망(hope), 절망(despair), 소망(wish). Polite: 실망해요. Adjective: 실망스럽다(disappointing). Common: 실망시키다(to disappoint someone).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm tired because I worked a lot today.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 피(疲 fatigued) + 곤(困 exhausted). Polite: 피곤해요. Common: 피곤한 하루(tiring day), 너무 피곤해서 잠들었어요(I was so tired I fell asleep). Related: 지치다(exhausted), 녹초가 되다(to be worn out, colloquial).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm hungry because I didn't eat breakfast.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean compound. 배(stomach) + 고프다(empty/craving). ㅡ irregular: 배고파요(polite), 배고팠어요(past). Common: 배고픈 사람(hungry person), 배가 너무 고파요(I'm so hungry). Opposite: 배부르다(full).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm full because I ate too much.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean compound. 배(stomach) + 부르다(full/swollen). 르 irregular: 배불러요(polite), 배불렀어요(past). Common: 배불리 먹다(to eat until full), 배가 불러요(my stomach is full). Opposite: 배고프다(hungry).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm thirsty after exercising.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean compound. 목(throat) + 마르다(dry). 르 irregular: 목말라요(polite), 목말랐어요(past). Literally 'throat is dry.' Common: 물이 마시고 싶어요(I want to drink water). Also figuratively: 자유에 목마르다(thirst for freedom).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm sleepy because I couldn't sleep last night.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 졸려요. Past: 졸렸어요. 졸리다(to feel sleepy, involuntary) vs 졸다(to doze off, action). Noun: 졸음(drowsiness). Common: 졸음운전(drowsy driving), 졸음이 쏟아지다(drowsiness hits). Related: 잠이 오다(sleep comes).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I have a headache. (My head hurts.)
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 아파요(polite), 아팠어요(past). Used for all types of pain and illness. Pattern: body part + 이/가 아프다. Common: 머리가 아프다(headache), 배가 아프다(stomachache), 마음이 아프다(heartache). Noun: 아픔(pain).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The weather is nice today.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 좋아요. Modifier: 좋은. Essential distinction: 좋다(adjective, something IS good) vs 좋아하다(verb, to actively LIKE). Common: 날씨가 좋다(nice weather), 기분이 좋다(feel good), 좋은 사람(good person). Opposite: 나쁘다, 싫다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I dislike spicy food.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 싫어요. Essential distinction: 싫다(adjective, dislike state) vs 싫어하다(verb, active disliking). Opposite of 좋다. Common: 하기 싫다(don't want to do), 보기 싫다(don't want to see), 매운 음식이 싫다(dislike spicy food).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This drama is really fun/interesting.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Compound adjective. 재미(fun/interest) + 있다(exist). Literally 'fun exists.' Polite: 재미있어요. Modifier: 재미있는. Common: 재미있는 영화(fun movie), 재미있게 놀다(have fun). Opposite: 재미없다. Adverb: 재미있게(in a fun way).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: That movie was boring.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Compound adjective. 재미(fun) + 없다(not exist). Literally 'fun does not exist.' Polite: 재미없어요. Modifier: 재미없는. Opposite of 재미있다. Compare: 지루하다(tedious from content), 심심하다(idle boredom). Common: 재미없는 수업(boring class).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm excited because I'm going on a trip tomorrow!
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 신나요. Past: 신났어요. Energetic, bubbly excitement, often child-like joy. Modifier: 신나는. Common: 신나는 음악(upbeat music), 신나는 여행(exciting trip), 신나게 놀다(have a blast). Related: 들뜨다(giddy), 흥분하다(worked up).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm frustrated because we can't communicate.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 답답해요. Has two uses: physical (stuffy room, chest tightness) and emotional (frustration from inability to communicate or make progress). Very common in Korean daily life. Common: 답답한 마음(frustrated feeling), 말이 안 통해서 답답하다(frustrated by miscommunication).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This sofa is really comfortable.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 편해요. Modifier: 편한. Physical comfort or ease of mind. More casual variant of 편안하다(formal). Common: 편한 옷(comfortable clothes), 마음이 편하다(peace of mind), 편하게 앉으세요(sit comfortably). Opposite: 불편하다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This chair is very uncomfortable.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean prefix 불(不 not) + native 편하다(comfortable). Polite: 불편해요. Physical discomfort or situational inconvenience. Common: 불편한 의자(uncomfortable chair), 불편한 진실(inconvenient truth). Opposite: 편하다. Related: 거북하다(uneasy, social).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm satisfied with this result.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 만(滿 full) + 족(足 sufficient/enough). Polite: 만족해요. Adjective form: 만족스럽다(satisfying). Common: 만족스러운 결과(satisfying result), 만족감(sense of satisfaction). Opposite: 불만족하다(dissatisfied). Noun: 만족(satisfaction).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 그때 더 열심히 공부할 걸 후회해요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I regret not studying harder back then.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 후(後 after) + 회(悔 regret). Polite: 후회해요. Literally 'to feel remorse afterward.' Common: 후회하지 않다(to have no regrets), 후회가 남다(lingering regrets), 후회해도 소용없다(regretting is useless). Noun: 후회(regret).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I miss my hometown.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 그리워요(polite), 그리웠어요(past). Noun: 그리움(longing/nostalgia). For people, places, or past times you yearn for. Common: 고향이 그립다(miss hometown), 그리운 사람(person you miss). Related: 보고 싶다(to miss someone).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm upset because my friend said something mean to me.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean compound. 속(inside/heart) + 상하다(to go bad/be hurt). Literally 'the inside is hurt.' Polite: 속상해요. Emotional hurt or upset feeling. Common: 속상한 일(upsetting matter), 마음이 속상하다(heart is upset). Related: 마음이 아프다(heartbroken).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel wronged because I got scolded even though I didn't do it.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: A distinctly Korean emotion with no perfect English equivalent. The feeling of being unfairly blamed, punished, or misunderstood. Polite: 억울해요. Common: 억울한 일을 당하다(suffer an injustice), 억울해서 눈물이 나다(cry from the injustice). Related: 분하다(resentful).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm excited because it's my first date.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 설레요. Past: 설렜어요. Fluttery, anticipatory excitement, often romantic or before a special event. Noun: 설렘(flutter, anticipation). Common: 설레는 마음(fluttering heart), 첫사랑의 설렘(flutter of first love). Related: 두근거리다(heart pounding).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel proud and fulfilled after finishing the project.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 뿌듯해요. A warm, personal sense of accomplishment and fulfillment. More intimate and self-directed than 자랑스럽다(proud, can be about others). Common: 뿌듯한 기분(sense of fulfillment), 일을 끝내고 뿌듯하다(feel fulfilled after finishing work). Noun: 뿌듯함.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be annoyed / to be irritated
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The bus isn't coming, so I'm annoyed.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 짜증나요. Very commonly used for minor everyday irritation. Noun: 짜증(irritation/annoyance). 짜증이 나다(to feel annoyed, state) vs 짜증을 내다(to express annoyance at someone, action). Related: 열받다(slang for ticked off), 신경 쓰이다(to be bothered).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be flustered / to be embarrassed
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was flustered because I was suddenly asked a question.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. Polite: 당황해요. The feeling of being caught off guard and not knowing how to react. Adjective: 당황스럽다(flustering). Common: 당황한 표정(flustered expression), 당황하지 마세요(don't be flustered). Related: 어리둥절하다(bewildered), 쩔쩔매다(to flounder).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel hurt / to feel let down / disappointed
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel hurt because my friend canceled our plans.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Distinctly Korean emotion. Polite: 서운해요. A gentle hurt or disappointment from someone close to you, more sadness than anger. No perfect English equivalent. Common: 서운한 마음(hurt feelings), 서운하게 생각하지 마세요(please don't feel hurt). Related: 섭섭하다(similar, slightly more casual).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel relieved / to be at ease
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was relieved because the test results were good.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 안(安 peace/safety) appears in 안전(safety), 안정(stability). 심(心 heart/mind) appears in 심장(heart), 양심(conscience), 관심(interest). Polite: 안심해요. Common: 안심이 되다(to feel relieved), 안심하세요(rest easy). Related: 마음을 놓다(to be at ease).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be bored / to be tedious
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 이 영화 너무 지루해요. 다른 거 볼까요?
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This movie is so boring. Shall we watch something else?
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 지루해요. Boredom caused by tedious, monotonous, or uninteresting content. Common: 지루한 수업(boring class), 지루한 영화(boring movie), 지루한 시간(tedious time). Opposite: 재미있다. Related: 지겹다(sick and tired of), 따분하다(dull).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel refreshed / to be fresh
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The morning air is refreshing. I feel good.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 상(爽 refreshing/crisp) + 쾌(快 pleasant/cheerful). Polite: 상쾌해요. A refreshed, invigorated feeling. Common: 상쾌한 아침(refreshing morning), 상쾌한 공기(fresh air), 기분이 상쾌하다(feel refreshed). Related: 산뜻하다(crisp/clean feeling).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be depressed / to feel gloomy
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: When it rains, I get gloomy.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 우울(憂鬱) means melancholy or gloom. Polite: 우울해요. Common: 우울한 날(gloomy day), 우울한 기분(depressed mood), 비가 오면 우울하다(feel gloomy when it rains). Noun: 우울증(depression, clinical). Related: 침울하다(somber, literary).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be excited / to be worked up
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The concert is tomorrow, so I'm so excited!
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 흥(興 excitement/interest) appears in 흥미(interest), 흥행(box office hit). 분(奮 vigor/rouse) appears in 분발하다(to rouse oneself). Polite: 흥분해요. Can be positive or negative excitement. Common: 흥분 상태(excited state). Passive: 흥분되다(to get excited).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be jealous / to feel jealousy
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I get jealous when my boyfriend talks to other girls.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 질(嫉 jealousy) + 투(妬 envy). Polite: 질투해요. Noun: 질투(jealousy). Common: 질투가 나다(to feel jealous), 질투심(jealous feelings), 질투를 부리다(to act jealous). Related: 부러워하다(to envy, less negative), 시기하다(to be envious).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be grateful / to be thankful
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm really grateful that you helped me.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 감(感 feel) appears in 감동(being moved), 감각(sense), 감정(emotion). 사(謝 thank) appears in 사과(apology), 사례(token of thanks). Polite: 감사해요. Formal: 감사합니다. Native Korean equivalent: 고맙다(thankful). 감사 is more formal than 고마움.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be absurd / to be bewildered / ridiculous
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 그 사람이 한 말이 너무 황당해요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: What that person said is so absurd.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 황당해요. Something so absurd or ridiculous that you are left speechless. Common: 황당한 상황(absurd situation), 황당한 이야기(ridiculous story), 너무 황당해서 말이 안 나왔어요(it was so absurd I was speechless). Related: 어이없다(dumbfounded).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel empty / to feel something is missing
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Now that my friend has left, my heart feels empty.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 허전해요. An emotional or physical feeling that something is missing or empty. Common: 마음이 허전하다(heart feels empty), 허전한 기분(feeling of emptiness), 밥을 안 먹으니 속이 허전하다(stomach feels empty without food). Related: 공허하다(hollow).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to feel reassured / to feel full and satisfied
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I ate a lot, so I feel full and satisfied.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 든든해요. Two distinct uses: physically satisfied after eating well, or emotionally secure and reassured. Common: 배가 든든하다(stomach is comfortably full), 든든한 사람(dependable/reliable person), 든든한 지원(solid support). Related: 믿음직하다(trustworthy).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to bluff / to exaggerate / to lie (slang)
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Don't bluff! Tell me the truth.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Casual slang. Polite: 뻥쳐요. Means to exaggerate, bluff, or tell a casual lie. Noun: 뻥(a fib/bluff). Common: 뻥이야!(That's a lie!), 뻥치지 마(don't lie), 뻥을 치다(to tell a fib). Used among friends in informal settings. Related: 거짓말하다(to lie, standard).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I had a mental meltdown when I saw the test results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Internet slang noun, short for 멘탈(mental) + 붕괴(collapse). Describes a state of mental overload or meltdown. Common: 멘붕이 오다(to have a meltdown), 멘붕 상태(meltdown state), 멘붕이었어요(I was in total shock). Used casually and humorously, not for clinical situations.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: You can speak confidently.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 당당해요. An unapologetically confident and dignified attitude. Adverb: 당당하게 or 당당히(confidently). Common: 당당한 태도(confident attitude), 당당하게 말하다(speak confidently), 당당한 모습(dignified appearance). Related: 자신감(self-confidence).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I was doubtful at first, but it was true.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 의(疑 doubt) + 심(心 heart/mind). Polite: 의심해요. Noun: 의심(suspicion/doubt). Common: 의심이 가다(to become suspicious), 의심의 여지가 없다(no room for doubt), 의심 많은 사람(suspicious person). Related: 의문(question/doubt), 수상하다(suspicious).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I really respect my parents.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 존(尊 honor/revere) appears in 존중(respect), 존재(existence). 경(敬 respect) appears in 경의(respect/tribute), 경어(honorific language). Polite: 존경해요. Common: 존경하는 분(respected person), 존경심(feelings of respect). Related: 존중하다(to respect, broader).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Don't ignore what I'm saying.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 무(無 nothing) + 시(視 look/see). Literally 'to look at as nothing.' Polite: 무시해요. Can imply looking down on someone. Passive: 무시당하다(to be ignored/disrespected). Common: 무시하면 안 돼요(you shouldn't ignore it), 무시하는 태도(dismissive attitude).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I don't want to receive pity.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 동(同 same/together) + 정(情 emotion/feeling). Literally 'to share the same emotion.' Polite: 동정해요. Noun: 동정(pity/sympathy). Can carry a negative connotation of condescension. Common: 동정심(feeling of sympathy), 동정은 필요 없어요(I don't need your pity).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).english: to be sick of; to be fed up
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm sick of it because it's the same menu every day.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 질려요. Past: 질렸어요. To be completely sick of or fed up with something, usually from overexposure. Common: 질리도록 먹다(eat until sick of it), 매일 같은 거라 질렸어요(sick of it because it's the same every day). Related: 지겹다(tired of), 물리다(fed up with food).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I've gotten used to life in Korea now.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 익숙해요. To be familiar or accustomed to something. Pattern: -에 익숙하다. 익숙해지다(to become familiar/get used to). Common: 한국 생활에 익숙하다(used to life in Korea), 익숙한 맛(familiar taste). Opposite: 낯설다(unfamiliar).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example: 처음 가는 곳이라 모든 게 낯설어요.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Everything feels unfamiliar because it's my first time here.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean compound. 낯(face/appearance) + 설다(unfamiliar/raw). Polite: 낯설어요. Something or someone that feels unfamiliar or strange. Modifier: 낯선. Common: 낯선 사람(stranger), 낯선 곳(unfamiliar place), 처음이라 낯설어요(it's unfamiliar because it's my first time). Opposite: 익숙하다.

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I fell in front of people and it was embarrassing.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 민망해요. Embarrassment or awkwardness from an uncomfortable social moment. Common: 민망한 상황(embarrassing situation), 민망한 실수(awkward mistake), 사람들 앞에서 민망했어요(it was embarrassing in front of people). Related: 창피하다(ashamed), 쑥스럽다(bashful).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I feel deflated because the exam was cancelled.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 허탈해요. A deflated, empty feeling when something you prepared for or anticipated falls through or amounts to nothing. Common: 허탈한 기분(deflated feeling), 시험이 취소돼서 허탈하다(feel deflated because the exam was cancelled). Related: 김이 빠지다(to lose steam), 맥이 풀리다(to go limp).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: I'm anxious while waiting for the results.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 초(焦 scorch/anxious) + 조(躁 restless/agitated). Polite: 초조해요. Nervous restlessness, stronger than 긴장되다. Common: 초조하게 기다리다(wait anxiously), 초조한 마음(anxious mind), 결과를 기다리며 초조하다(anxious waiting for results). Related: 안절부절못하다(unable to sit still).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: Hearing that news, I really feel sorry about it.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 안타까워요(polite), 안타까웠어요(past). Sympathetic sadness felt for someone else's misfortune. Very commonly used. Common: 안타깝게도(unfortunately), 안타까운 소식(sad/unfortunate news), 참 안타까워요(how unfortunate). Related: 불쌍하다(pitiful).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: The answer is a bit vague.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 애매해요. Very common in daily Korean for something vague, ambiguous, or unclear. Common: 애매한 대답(vague answer), 애매한 상황(ambiguous situation), 애매한 표현(unclear expression). Emphatic form: 애매모호하다(even more vague). Related: 모호하다(obscure).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: This problem is too complicated.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 복(複 multiple/complex) + 잡(雜 mixed/miscellaneous). Polite: 복잡해요. For abstract complexity or physical crowding. Common: 복잡한 문제(complicated problem), 길이 복잡하다(streets are confusing), 머리가 복잡하다(mind is cluttered). Opposite: 단순하다(simple).

감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).example_en: It was a simpler problem than I thought.
감정 & 상태 (Emotions & States).notes: Sino-Korean. 단(單 single/sole) + 순(純 pure/simple). Polite: 단순해요. Adverb: 단순히(simply). Opposite of 복잡하다. Can mean simple-minded in some contexts. Common: 단순한 실수(simple mistake), 단순한 문제(straightforward problem). Related: 간단하다(brief/easy).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean color adjective. ㅎ irregular: 빨개요(polite), 빨갰어요(past). Modifier form: 빨간(빨간 사과 = red apple). Intensified: 새빨갛다(bright/vivid red). Related literary form: 붉다(red, poetic). Common: 빨간색(red color), 빨간 입술(red lips), 얼굴이 빨개지다(face turns red).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The sky is really blue today.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean color adjective. ㅎ irregular: 파래요(polite), 파랬어요(past). Modifier: 파란(파란 하늘 = blue sky). Intensified: 새파랗다(vivid blue). Traditionally 파랗다 can include green (traffic lights: 파란불). Common: 파란색(blue color), 파란 바다(blue sea).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The leaves turn yellow in autumn.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean color adjective. ㅎ irregular: 노래요(polite), 노랬어요(past). Modifier: 노란(노란 꽃 = yellow flower). Intensified: 샛노랗다(bright yellow). Common: 노란색(yellow color), 노란 나뭇잎(yellow leaves in autumn), 노란 병아리(yellow chick).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: It snowed so the world is white.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean color adjective. ㅎ irregular: 하얘요(polite), 하얬어요(past). Modifier: 하얀(하얀 눈 = white snow). Intensified: 새하얗다(pure white). Alternative form: 흰/흰색(white, also common). Common: 하얀 구름(white cloud), 얼굴이 하얘지다(face turns white/pale).

Native Korean color adjective. ㅎ irregular: 까매요(polite), 까맸어요(past). Modifier: 까만(까만 머리 = black hair). Intensified: 새까맣다(jet black). Alternative form: 검은/검은색(black, also common). Common: 까만 밤(black night), 까만 눈동자(black pupils).

초록(green) + 색(色 color). A native Korean color name. Common: 초록불(green traffic light), 초록 나무(green tree), 초록색 잔디(green lawn). Formal Sino-Korean equivalent: 녹색(綠色). Poetic: 푸르다(blue-green). Note: 초록 can be used without 색 as a modifier.

Sino-Korean. 주(朱 vermilion) + 황(黃 yellow) + 색(色 color). Literally 'vermilion-yellow color,' describing the mix between red and yellow. Common: 주황색 신호등(orange traffic light), 주황색 석양(orange sunset). Alternative: 오렌지색(from English, also commonly used).

보라(purple, native Korean origin) + 색(色 color). Common: 보라색 꽃(purple flower), 보라색 하늘(purple sky at sunset). Related colors: 자주색(dark purple/magenta), 라벤더색(lavender), 연보라(light purple). K-pop fans may associate with BTS's 보라해(I purple you).

Sino-Korean. 분(粉 powder) + 홍(紅 red) + 색(色 color). Literally 'powdered red,' describing the pale red of pink. 홍(紅) appears in 홍보(publicity), 홍수(flood). Common: 분홍색 장미(pink rose), 분홍빛(pink hue). Alternative: 핑크색(from English, also used).

Sino-Korean. 회(灰 ash) + 색(色 color). Literally 'ash color.' 회(灰) relates to ashes/gray. Common: 회색 하늘(gray sky, implies overcast/gloomy), 회색 머리(gray hair), 회색 지대(gray area). Related: 잿빛(ashen, poetic), 은색(silver).

Sino-Korean. 갈(褐 brown) + 색(色 color). Common: 갈색 머리(brown hair), 갈색 눈(brown eyes), 갈색 가죽(brown leather). Related browns: 밤색(chestnut brown), 고동색(dark reddish brown), 황토색(yellowish earth tone), 베이지색(beige).

Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 커요(polite, ㅡ drops), 컸어요(past). Modifier: 큰. For size and height (키가 크다 = to be tall). Common: 큰 집(big house), 큰 소리(loud sound), 큰일 나다(big trouble happens). Noun: 크기(size). Opposite: 작다.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: These clothes are too small for me.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean. Regular conjugation: 작아요(polite), 작았어요(past). Modifier: 작은. Common: 작은 가게(small shop), 작은 소리(quiet sound), 키가 작다(to be short in height). Noun: 작음. Opposite: 크다. Don't confuse with 적다(few in quantity).

Native Korean. Regular: 많아요(polite). Modifier: 많은. Adverb: 많이(a lot, very common). Common: 사람이 많다(lots of people), 돈이 많다(wealthy), 많이 드세요(please eat a lot, polite). Opposite: 적다(few). 많이 is one of the most frequently used Korean adverbs.

Native Korean. Regular: 적어요(polite). Modifier: 적은. For quantity being few or small. Common: 적은 양(small amount), 사람이 적다(few people). Homophone warning: 적다(to write down) is a completely different verb. Opposite: 많다(many). Related: 드물다(rare).

Native Korean. Regular: 길어요(polite). Modifier: 긴(irregular short form, NOT 길은). Common: 긴 머리(long hair), 긴 시간(long time), 길이가 길다(length is long). Noun: 길이(length). Opposite: 짧다(short). Note: 길(road/street) is a separate word.

Native Korean. Regular: 짧아요(polite). Modifier: 짧은. Pronunciation: [짤따]. For length, not height. Common: 짧은 머리(short hair), 짧은 시간(short time), 짧은 글(short writing). For height use 키가 작다, not 짧다. Opposite: 길다(long).

Native Korean. Regular: 넓어요(polite). Modifier: 넓은. Pronunciation: [널따]. For area/width/spaciousness. Common: 넓은 방(spacious room), 넓은 마음(broad-minded), 넓은 땅(wide land). Noun: 넓이(area/width). Opposite: 좁다(narrow).

Native Korean. Regular: 좁아요(polite). Modifier: 좁은. For cramped or narrow spaces. Common: 좁은 길(narrow road), 좁은 공간(cramped space), 시야가 좁다(narrow-minded, figurative). Opposite: 넓다(wide). Related: 비좁다(cramped, emphatic form).

Native Korean. Regular: 높아요(polite). Modifier: 높은. For height of things, not people (use 키가 크다 for people). Common: 높은 산(high mountain), 높은 건물(tall building), 높은 가격(high price). Noun: 높이(height). Opposite: 낮다(low).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: This table is a bit low.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean. Regular: 낮아요(polite). Modifier: 낮은. Common: 낮은 목소리(low voice), 낮은 가격(low price), 낮은 온도(low temperature). Homophone warning: 낮(daytime) is a separate noun. Opposite: 높다(high). Related: 저(low, Sino-Korean prefix).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 무거워요(polite), 무거웠어요(past). Modifier: 무거운. Common: 무거운 짐(heavy luggage), 무거운 책(heavy book), 마음이 무겁다(heavy-hearted). Noun: 무게(weight). Opposite: 가볍다(light). Related: 무겁게 느끼다(to feel weighed down).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 가벼워요(polite), 가벼웠어요(past). Modifier: 가벼운. Physical or figurative lightness. Common: 가벼운 운동(light exercise), 가벼운 마음(lighthearted), 가벼운 식사(light meal). Opposite: 무겁다(heavy). Adverb: 가볍게(lightly).

Native Korean. 르 irregular: 빨라요(polite, 르→ㄹㄹ), 빨랐어요(past). Modifier: 빠른. Common: 빠른 속도(fast speed), 시간이 빠르다(time flies), 빠른 걸음(quick steps). Adverb: 빨리(quickly, extremely common). Opposite: 느리다(slow).

Native Korean. Polite: 느려요. Past: 느렸어요. Modifier: 느린. Common: 느린 속도(slow speed), 느린 인터넷(slow internet), 느린 걸음(slow steps). Adverb: 느리게(slowly). Opposite: 빠르다(fast). Related: 천천히(slowly, more commonly used as adverb).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 새로워요(polite), 새로웠어요(past). Modifier: 새로운. From 새(new) + 롭다(quality suffix). Common: 새로운 시작(new beginning), 새로운 경험(new experience), 새로운 친구(new friend). Related: 새(new, prefix), 신선하다(fresh).

Native Korean compound. 오래(a long time) + 되다(to become). Polite: 오래돼요. Modifier: 오래된. Only for things and relationships, NOT people's age (use 나이가 많다). Common: 오래된 건물(old building), 오래된 친구(long-time friend). Related: 낡다(worn out/shabby).

Native Korean. Polite: 좋아요. Modifier: 좋은. Essential distinction: 좋다(adjective: it IS good) vs 좋아하다(verb: to actively LIKE). Common: 좋은 날씨(nice weather), 좋은 사람(good person), 기분이 좋다(feel good), 사이가 좋다(get along well). Opposite: 나쁘다.

Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 나빠요(polite), 나빴어요(past). Modifier: 나쁜. Common: 나쁜 습관(bad habit), 날씨가 나쁘다(bad weather), 기분이 나쁘다(feel bad), 나쁜 사람(bad person). Opposite: 좋다(good). Related: 안 좋다(not good, softer alternative).

Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 예뻐요(polite, ㅡ drops and ㅃ tensifies), 예뻤어요(past). Modifier: 예쁜. For women, children, objects, and appearances. Common: 예쁜 꽃(pretty flower), 예쁜 얼굴(pretty face), 예쁘게 입다(dress prettily). More literary: 아름답다(beautiful).

Compound verb. 잘(well) + 생기다(to be formed/created). Standard form uses past tense: 잘생겼어요. Modifier: 잘생긴(잘생긴 배우 = handsome actor). Primarily for male attractiveness. Common: 잘생긴 남자(handsome man). Related: 멋있다(cool/stylish, gender-neutral), 미남(handsome man, Sino-Korean).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 귀여워요(polite), 귀여웠어요(past). Modifier: 귀여운. For cute things: babies, animals, small objects. Common: 귀여운 강아지(cute puppy), 귀여운 아기(cute baby), 귀여운 캐릭터(cute character). Noun: 귀여움(cuteness). Related: 앙증맞다(adorably small).

Native Korean. Polite: 깨끗해요. Modifier: 깨끗한. Adverb: 깨끗하게 or 깨끗이(cleanly). For physical cleanliness or figurative purity. Common: 깨끗한 방(clean room), 깨끗한 물(clean water), 깨끗하게 청소하다(clean thoroughly). Opposite: 더럽다(dirty). Related: 청결하다(hygienic, formal).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: Your hands are dirty. Wash them.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 더러워요(polite), 더러웠어요(past). Modifier: 더러운. Physical dirt or figurative vulgarity. Common: 더러운 손(dirty hands), 더러운 옷(dirty clothes), 더러운 말(dirty language/profanity). Opposite: 깨끗하다(clean). Related: 지저분하다(messy/untidy).

Native Korean. Regular: 밝아요(polite). Modifier: 밝은. For light, color, personality, or outlook. Common: 밝은 미래(bright future), 밝은 성격(bright/cheerful personality), 밝은 색(bright color), 밝은 표정(bright expression). Opposite: 어둡다(dark). Related: 환하다(radiant/bright).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 어두워요(polite), 어두웠어요(past). Modifier: 어두운. For lack of light or figuratively somber. Common: 어두운 밤(dark night), 어두운 방(dark room), 어두운 표정(dark/somber expression). Noun: 어둠(darkness). Opposite: 밝다(bright).

Native Korean. Polite: 따뜻해요. Modifier: 따뜻한. Physical warmth or emotional warmth. Common: 따뜻한 날씨(warm weather), 따뜻한 물(warm water), 따뜻한 마음(warm heart), 따뜻한 말(warm words). Opposite: 차갑다(cold to touch). Related: 따스하다(cozy warmth).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 차가워요(polite), 차가웠어요(past). Modifier: 차가운. For cold things you touch AND cold personalities. Common: 차가운 물(cold water), 차가운 손(cold hands), 차가운 사람(cold person). Opposite: 따뜻하다(warm). Compare: 춥다(cold weather).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 뜨거워요(polite), 뜨거웠어요(past). Modifier: 뜨거운. For hot things you touch. Common: 뜨거운 물(hot water), 뜨거운 커피(hot coffee), 뜨거운 눈물(hot tears, figurative). Compare: 덥다(hot weather, different word). Opposite: 차갑다(cold to touch).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 부드러워요(polite), 부드러웠어요(past). Modifier: 부드러운. For texture, personality, or manner. Common: 부드러운 피부(soft skin), 부드러운 목소리(gentle voice), 부드러운 빵(soft bread). Opposite: 딱딱하다(hard/stiff). Adverb: 부드럽게(gently/softly).

Native Korean, onomatopoeic origin. Polite: 딱딱해요. Modifier: 딱딱한. Physical hardness or figurative stiffness. Common: 딱딱한 빵(hard/stale bread), 딱딱한 의자(hard chair), 딱딱한 분위기(stiff/awkward atmosphere). Opposite: 부드럽다(soft/gentle). Related: 뻣뻣하다(rigid).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 쉬워요(polite), 쉬웠어요(past). Modifier: 쉬운. Common: 쉬운 문제(easy problem), 쉬운 말(simple/easy language), 쉽게 할 수 있어요(I can do it easily). Adverb: 쉽게(easily). Opposite: 어렵다(difficult). Related: 간단하다(simple/brief).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 어려워요(polite), 어려웠어요(past). Modifier: 어려운. Two uses: difficulty and hardship. Common: 어려운 시험(difficult exam), 어려운 상황(difficult situation), 생활이 어렵다(life is hard/in hardship). Opposite: 쉽다(easy). Adverb: 어렵게(with difficulty).

Sino-Korean. 중(重 heavy/weighty) appears in 중심(center), 중대하다(serious/grave). 요(要 essential/need) appears in 필요(necessity), 요점(key point). Polite: 중요해요. Modifier: 중요한. Common: 중요한 약속(important appointment), 제일 중요하다(most important). Adverb: 중요하게.

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: That road is dangerous at night.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Sino-Korean. 위(危 danger/peril) appears in 위기(crisis), 위태롭다(precarious). 험(險 steep/risky) appears in 험하다(rough/harsh), 모험(adventure). Polite: 위험해요. Common: 위험한 행동(dangerous behavior), 위험 지역(danger zone). Opposite: 안전하다(safe).

Native Korean. Polite: 연해요. Modifier: 연한. For pale or light colors and mild flavors. Pattern: 연한 + color name (연한 파란색 = light blue, 연한 분홍색 = light pink). Common: 연한 색(light color), 연한 맛(mild taste). Opposite: 진하다(dark/deep/strong).

Native Korean. Polite: 진해요. Modifier: 진한. For dark/deep colors and strong flavors. Common: 진한 빨간색(deep red), 진한 커피(strong coffee), 진한 맛(rich/strong flavor), 진한 화장(heavy makeup). Opposite: 연하다(light/pale). Related: 짙다(dense/thick, for color/fog).

Sino-Korean. 화(華 splendid/magnificent) + 려(麗 beautiful/lovely). Polite: 화려해요. Modifier: 화려한. For flashy, colorful, dazzling appearance. Common: 화려한 옷(flashy clothes), 화려한 무대(dazzling stage), 화려한 조명(flashy lighting). Opposite: 수수하다(plain/modest).

Native Korean. Polite: 수수해요. Modifier: 수수한. Plain, modest, understated, with positive connotation of good taste. Opposite of 화려하다. Common: 수수한 옷차림(modest outfit), 수수한 디자인(understated design). Related: 소박하다(humble/simple), 담백하다(clean/unadorned).

Native Korean. Polite: 튼튼해요. Modifier: 튼튼한. For physical durability of objects or strong health. Common: 튼튼한 가방(sturdy bag), 몸이 튼튼하다(physically strong/healthy), 튼튼한 기초(solid foundation). Related: 건강하다(healthy), 단단하다(solid/firm), 견고하다(robust).

Sino-Korean stem. 약(弱 weak). Polite: 약해요. Modifier: 약한. Physical or figurative weakness. Common: 약한 체질(weak constitution), 추위에 약하다(weak against cold), 약한 불(low heat for cooking). Opposite: 강하다(strong). Noun: 약점(weakness/weak point).

Native Korean. ㅂ irregular: 두꺼워요(polite), 두꺼웠어요(past). Modifier: 두꺼운. For thickness of flat objects. Common: 두꺼운 책(thick book), 두꺼운 옷(thick clothes), 두꺼운 이불(thick blanket). Noun: 두께(thickness). Opposite: 얇다(thin). Related: 굵다(thick for round objects like rope).

Native Korean. Regular: 얇아요(polite). Modifier: 얇은. Pronunciation: [얄따]. For thin flat objects. Common: 얇은 종이(thin paper), 얇은 옷(thin clothes), 얇은 피부(thin skin). Opposite: 두껍다(thick). Related: 가늘다(thin/slender, for lines, strings, or limbs).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: This cake is moist and delicious.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean, mimetic/sensory word. Polite: 촉촉해요. Modifier: 촉촉한. Pleasant moisture, positive connotation. Common: 촉촉한 피부(moist/dewy skin), 촉촉한 케이크(moist cake). Compare: 축축하다(damp/clammy, negative connotation). Related: 보습(moisturizing), 촉촉하게 유지하다(keep moisturized).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: I like this chicken because it's crispy.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean, onomatopoeic. Polite: 바삭해요. Modifier: 바삭한. Ideal crispy texture for fried food. Doubled form: 바삭바삭하다(very crispy). Common: 바삭한 치킨(crispy chicken), 바삭한 과자(crunchy snack), 바삭하게 튀기다(fry until crispy). Related: 아삭아삭하다(crunchy, for vegetables).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: I ate a sweet strawberry cake.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 달콤해요. Modifier: 달콤한. A pleasant, appealing sweetness, more poetic than basic 달다(sweet). Common: 달콤한 초콜릿(sweet chocolate), 달콤한 말(sweet/flattering words), 달콤한 꿈(sweet dream). Related: 새콤달콤하다(sweet and sour), 감미롭다(lusciously sweet).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The sesame oil smells nutty and savory.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 고소해요. Modifier: 고소한. A uniquely Korean flavor concept with no exact English equivalent: the toasty, nutty, savory taste of sesame oil, roasted nuts, or toasted grain. Common: 고소한 참기름(nutty sesame oil), 고소한 냄새(toasty aroma). Essential vocabulary for describing Korean food.

Sino-Korean. 신(新 new) appears in 신문(newspaper), 신입(newcomer). 선(鮮 fresh/vivid) appears in 선명하다(vivid/clear). Polite: 신선해요. Common: 신선한 과일(fresh fruit), 신선한 공기(fresh air), 신선한 아이디어(fresh idea). Related: 싱싱하다(fresh, especially for produce).

색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).example_en: The milk has gone bad. Throw it away.
색깔 & 형용사 (Colors & Adjectives).notes: Native Korean verb. Polite: 상해요. Past: 상했어요. Primarily for food spoiling. Common: 우유가 상하다(milk goes bad), 음식이 상하다(food spoils), 더위에 상하다(spoil in the heat). Also figuratively: 기분이 상하다(feelings are hurt), 속이 상하다(feel upset). Related: 썩다(to rot).

Native Korean. Polite: 익어요. Past: 익었어요. Two main meanings: fruit ripening and food being cooked. Common: 바나나가 익다(banana ripens), 고기가 익다(meat is cooked), 잘 익은 수박(well-ripened watermelon). Related: 덜 익다(underripe/undercooked), 날것(raw). Also figurative: 실력이 익다(skills mature).

Native Korean noun (not a verb). 날(raw/uncooked) + 것(thing). Common: 날것으로 먹다(to eat raw), 날생선(raw fish), 날달걀(raw egg), 날고기(raw meat). In Korea, raw fish (회) is popular. Related: 생(生 raw/fresh, Sino-Korean prefix), 익히다(to cook something).

Sino-Korean. 적(適 suitable/fitting) + 당(當 proper/appropriate). Polite: 적당해요. Modifier: 적당한. Common: 적당한 가격(reasonable price), 적당한 양(moderate amount), 적당히 하다(do things in moderation). Adverb: 적당히(moderately). Related: 알맞다(just right, native Korean).

Sino-Korean. 충(充 fill/charge) appears in 충전(charging), 충실하다(faithful). 분(分 portion/share) appears in 부분(part), 분량(amount). Polite: 충분해요. Adverb: 충분히(sufficiently). Common: 충분한 시간(enough time), 충분한 양(sufficient amount). Opposite: 부족하다.

Sino-Korean. 부(不 not) + 족(足 enough/sufficient). 족(足) appears in 만족(satisfaction), 자족(self-sufficiency). Polite: 부족해요. Common: 잠이 부족하다(lack of sleep), 경험이 부족하다(lack experience), 부족한 점(shortcomings). Opposite: 충분하다(sufficient).

Sino-Korean. 완(完 complete) appears in 완전(complete), 완성(completion). 벽(璧 jade disc, meaning flawless). Polite: 완벽해요. Modifier: 완벽한. Adverb: 완벽하게(perfectly). Common: 완벽한 계획(perfect plan), 완벽한 날씨(perfect weather). Related: 완전하다(complete), 흠잡을 데 없다(flawless).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: What are you doing?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: The most versatile Korean verb. Attaches to Sino-Korean nouns to create verbs: 공부하다(study), 운동하다(exercise), 요리하다(cook), 일하다(work). Polite: 해요. Past: 했어요. Imperative: 하세요. Also used in many grammatical patterns like -고 싶다(want to do).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I go to school.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 가요. Past: 갔어요. Imperative: 가세요. Honorific: 가시다. Common: 학교에 가다(go to school), 집에 가다(go home), 여행을 가다(go on a trip). Related: 다니다(to commute/attend regularly), 떠나다(to depart).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: My friend comes to my house.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Irregular contraction: 와요(polite, 오+아→와, NOT 오어요). Past: 왔어요. Honorific: 오시다. Common: 여기로 오세요(come here, polite), 비가 오다(it rains), 봄이 오다(spring comes). Related: 돌아오다(come back), 들어오다(come in).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Did you eat lunch?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 먹어요. Past: 먹었어요. Honorific: 드시다(much more respectful). Common: 밥 먹다(eat a meal), 약 먹다(take medicine, unique to Korean), 밥 먹었어요?(common greeting meaning 'have you eaten?'). Related: 식사하다(to dine, formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I drink a lot of water.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 마셔요(시+어→셔, NOT 마시어요). Past: 마셨어요. Honorific: 드시다. Common: 물 마시다(drink water), 커피 마시다(drink coffee), 술 마시다(drink alcohol). Related: 음료수(beverage), 한잔하다(to have a drink, casual).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I slept well last night.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 자요(ㅏ+아 contracts, NOT 자어요). Past: 잤어요. Honorific: 주무시다(much more polite). Common: 잘 자요(good night), 늦게 자다(sleep late), 일찍 자다(sleep early). Related: 낮잠 자다(take a nap), 잠을 자다(to sleep).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to wake up, to get up
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wake up at 7 every morning.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean compound. 일(rise) + 어나다. Polite: 일어나요(ㅏ+아 contracts). Past: 일어났어요. Two meanings: waking up and standing up. Common: 아침에 일어나다(wake up in morning), 자리에서 일어나다(stand up from seat). Related: 기상하다(to rise, formal/military).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wash my hands before eating.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 씻어요. Past: 씻었어요. Pronunciation: [씯따]. For washing body parts or objects. Common: 손을 씻다(wash hands), 얼굴을 씻다(wash face), 그릇을 씻다(wash dishes). Related: 세수하다(wash face, common compound), 세탁하다(do laundry, formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: What are you going to wear today?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 입어요. Past: 입었어요. Only for clothes worn on the torso and body. Shoes use 신다, hats use 쓰다, glasses use 쓰다. Common: 옷을 입다(put on clothes), 코트를 입다(wear a coat). Opposite: 벗다(take off). Related: 차려입다(dress up).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I take off my shoes when I enter the house.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 벗어요. Past: 벗었어요. To take off clothes, shoes, hats, or accessories. Common: 신발을 벗다(take off shoes, essential Korean custom indoors), 모자를 벗다(take off hat), 외투를 벗다(take off coat). Opposite: 입다/신다/쓰다 depending on item.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I go out wearing sneakers.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 신어요. Past: 신었어요. Exclusively for footwear: shoes, socks, slippers, boots. Common: 신발을 신다(put on shoes), 양말을 신다(put on socks), 운동화를 신다(put on sneakers). Opposite: 벗다(take off). Related: 신발(shoes).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: May I sit here?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 앉아요(stem vowel ㅏ takes 아). Past: 앉았어요. Pronunciation: [안따]. Imperative: 앉으세요(please sit). Common: 여기 앉으세요(please sit here), 앉아서 기다리다(sit and wait), 의자에 앉다(sit in a chair). Opposite: 서다(stand), 일어나다(stand up).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I wait standing in line.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 서요(ㅓ+어 contracts). Past: 섰어요. Common: 줄을 서다(stand in line), 멈춰 서다(stop and stand), 앞에 서다(stand in front). Ongoing state: 서 있다(to be standing). Related: 일어서다(to stand up from sitting). Opposite: 앉다(sit).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I walk in the park.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. ㄷ irregular: 걸어요(polite, ㄷ→ㄹ before vowel). Past: 걸었어요. Common: 공원에서 걷다(walk in the park), 걸어서 가다(go on foot), 걸어 다니다(walk around). Noun: 걸음(a step), 산책(a stroll). Related: 거닐다(to stroll leisurely).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The children are running in the playground.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 뛰어요. Past: 뛰었어요. Two meanings: running and jumping. Common: 뛰어가다(run toward), 줄넘기를 뛰다(jump rope), 계단을 뛰어 올라가다(run up stairs). Related: 달리다(to run, more specific to running), 점프하다(to jump, loanword).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to see, to watch, to look
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I watch movies on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 봐요(보+아→봐). Past: 봤어요. Extremely versatile. Common: 영화를 보다(watch a movie), 시험을 보다(take an exam), 책을 보다(read/look at a book), 의사를 보다(see a doctor). Honorific: 보시다. Related: 바라보다(to gaze at), 쳐다보다(to stare).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I listen to music often.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. ㄷ irregular: 들어요(polite, ㄷ→ㄹ before vowel). Past: 들었어요. Common: 음악을 듣다(listen to music), 이야기를 듣다(hear a story), 수업을 듣다(take a class/course). Noun: 듣기(listening skill). Related: 경청하다(to listen attentively, formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to speak, to say, to tell
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please speak slowly.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean compound. 말(words/speech) + 하다(do). Polite: 말해요(하→해). Past: 말했어요. Common: 천천히 말하다(speak slowly), 한국어로 말하다(speak in Korean), 솔직하게 말하다(speak honestly). Honorific: 말씀하시다. Related: 이야기하다(to talk/chat), 대화하다(to converse).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm reading an interesting book these days.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 읽어요. Past: 읽었어요. Pronunciation: [일따] (ㄺ→ㄱ is silent before consonant). Common: 책을 읽다(read a book), 신문을 읽다(read newspaper), 소리 내서 읽다(read aloud). Noun: 독서(reading as a hobby). Related: 읽기(reading skill).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I write in my diary every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 써요(polite, ㅡ drops). Past: 썼어요. Multiple meanings: 글을 쓰다(to write), 돈을 쓰다(to spend money), 도구를 쓰다(to use a tool), 모자를 쓰다(to wear a hat). Context determines meaning. Related: 작성하다(to compose, formal), 사용하다(to use, formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I make a cake on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 만들어요. Past: 만들었어요. ㄹ verb (ㄹ drops before ㄴ,ㅂ,ㅅ: 만드는, 만듭니다, 만드세요). Common: 음식을 만들다(make food), 친구를 만들다(make friends), 계획을 만들다(make a plan). Related: 제작하다(to produce, formal), 창작하다(to create).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I buy fruit at the market.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 사요(ㅏ+아 contracts). Past: 샀어요. Common: 선물을 사다(buy a gift), 시장에서 사다(buy at the market), 뭐 살 거예요?(what will you buy?). Related: 구매하다(to purchase, formal), 구입하다(to procure). Opposite: 팔다(to sell).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: This store sells bread.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 팔아요(ㅏ takes 아). Past: 팔았어요. ㄹ verb (ㄹ drops before ㄴ,ㅂ,ㅅ: 파는, 팝니다, 파세요). Common: 물건을 팔다(sell goods), 시장에서 팔다(sell at market). Related: 판매하다(to sell, formal). Opposite: 사다(to buy).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I give a present to my friend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 줘요(주+어→줘). Past: 줬어요. Also used as auxiliary verb: -아/어 주다(do something as a favor for someone). Common: 선물을 주다(give a gift), 도와 주다(help someone). Honorific for giving to elders: 드리다. Opposite: 받다(receive).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I received a birthday present.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 받아요(ㅏ takes 아). Past: 받았어요. Common: 선물을 받다(receive a gift), 전화를 받다(answer a phone call), 월급을 받다(receive salary), 스트레스를 받다(get stressed). Opposite: 주다(give). Related: 수령하다(to receive, formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please open the window.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 열어요. Past: 열었어요. ㄹ verb. Common: 문을 열다(open a door), 창문을 열다(open a window), 가게를 열다(open a shop/start a business), 마음을 열다(open one's heart). Opposite: 닫다(close). Passive: 열리다(to be opened).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please close the door.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 닫아요(ㅏ takes 아). Past: 닫았어요. Common: 문을 닫다(close a door), 눈을 닫다(close one's eyes), 가게를 닫다(close a shop). Opposite: 열다(open). Passive: 닫히다(to be closed). Related: 잠그다(to lock, a step beyond closing).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please turn on the light.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 켜요(ㅕ+어 contracts). Past: 켰어요. For turning on lights, electronics, or engines. Common: 불을 켜다(turn on the light), TV를 켜다(turn on TV), 에어컨을 켜다(turn on AC). Opposite: 끄다(turn off). Passive: 켜지다(to be turned on).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I turn off the light before sleeping.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. ㅡ irregular: 꺼요(polite, ㅡ drops). Past: 껐어요. For turning off lights, electronics, or flames. Common: 불을 끄다(turn off the light), 핸드폰을 끄다(turn off phone), 컴퓨터를 끄다(turn off computer). Opposite: 켜다(turn on). Passive: 꺼지다(to go off).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm looking for my wallet.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 찾아요(ㅏ takes 아). Past: 찾았어요. Multiple meanings: to find, to look for, to pick up, to withdraw. Common: 길을 찾다(find the way), 사람을 찾다(look for someone), 돈을 찾다(withdraw money from bank), 짐을 찾다(pick up luggage).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Please wait here for a moment.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 기다려요(리+어→려). Past: 기다렸어요. Common: 버스를 기다리다(wait for bus), 잠깐만 기다려 주세요(please wait a moment), 오래 기다리다(wait a long time). Related: 대기하다(to stand by, formal). Noun: 기다림(waiting).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I'm meeting a friend tomorrow.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 만나요(ㅏ+아 contracts). Past: 만났어요. Common: 친구를 만나다(meet a friend), 만나서 반갑습니다(nice to meet you), 우연히 만나다(meet by chance). Related: 마주치다(to bump into), 만남(a meeting/encounter).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I call my mom.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Sino-Korean compound. 전(電 electricity) + 화(話 speech) + 하다. Polite: 전화해요(하→해). Common: 전화를 걸다(make a call), 전화를 받다(answer a call), 전화번호(phone number). Related: 통화하다(to talk on the phone), 문자하다(to text).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I study Korean every day.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Sino-Korean compound. 공(工 work/craft) + 부(夫 man, implies effort) + 하다. Polite: 공부해요(하→해). Common: 한국어를 공부하다(study Korean), 열심히 공부하다(study hard), 시험 공부(exam study). Related: 학습하다(to learn, formal), 수업(class/lesson).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I work at a company.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native compound. 일(work) + 하다. Polite: 일해요(하→해). Common: 회사에서 일하다(work at a company), 열심히 일하다(work hard), 일을 하다(to do work). Related: 근무하다(to be on duty, formal), 직장(workplace), 직업(occupation/job).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to rest, to take a break
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I rest at home on weekends.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 쉬어요. Past: 쉬었어요. Two meanings: to rest AND to breathe (숨을 쉬다). Common: 좀 쉬다(rest a bit), 쉬는 날(day off), 주말에 쉬다(rest on weekends). Related: 휴식(rest, formal noun), 휴가(vacation), 쉬엄쉬엄(taking it easy).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Class starts at 9 o'clock.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Sino-Korean compound. 시(始 begin) + 작(作 make/do) + 하다. Polite: 시작해요(하→해). Common: 수업이 시작하다(class starts), 새로 시작하다(start fresh), 시작이 반이다(starting is half the battle, proverb). Intransitive: 시작되다(to be started). Opposite: 끝나다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Class ends at 12 o'clock.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean compound. 끝(end) + 나다(come out). Polite: 끝나요(ㅏ+아 contracts). Past: 끝났어요. Intransitive (things end by themselves). Common: 수업이 끝나다(class ends), 일이 끝나다(work ends). Transitive counterpart: 끝내다(to finish something actively). Opposite: 시작하다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I arrived at the airport.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Sino-Korean compound. 도(到 arrive/reach) + 착(着 land/attach) + 하다. Polite: 도착해요(하→해). Common: 공항에 도착하다(arrive at airport), 도착 시간(arrival time), 무사히 도착하다(arrive safely). Opposite: 출발하다(depart). Related: 도달하다(to reach, formal).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: The train is departing soon.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Sino-Korean compound. 출(出 go out/exit) + 발(發 release/send) + 하다. Polite: 출발해요(하→해). Common: 기차가 출발하다(train departs), 출발 시간(departure time), 내일 출발하다(depart tomorrow). Opposite: 도착하다(arrive). Related: 떠나다(to leave, native Korean).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Let's hang out together on the weekend.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 놀아요. Past: 놀았어요. ㄹ verb (ㄹ drops before ㄴ,ㅂ,ㅅ: 노는, 놉니다, 노세요). Means to play AND to hang out. Common: 친구와 놀다(hang out with friend), 놀이터(playground), 놀이공원(amusement park), 신나게 놀다(have a blast).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I like Korean food.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native compound. 좋아(from 좋다, good) + 하다. Polite: 좋아해요(하→해). Critical distinction from 좋다(adjective: it IS good): 좋아하다 is an active VERB meaning to like. Common: 한국 음식을 좋아하다(like Korean food), 뭘 좋아해요?(what do you like?). Opposite: 싫어하다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I hate lies.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native compound. 싫어(from 싫다, dislike) + 하다. Polite: 싫어해요(하→해). Active verb meaning to dislike, distinct from 싫다(adjective). Common: 거짓말을 싫어하다(hate lies), 뭘 싫어해요?(what do you dislike?). Opposite: 좋아하다(to like). Stronger: 미워하다(to hate).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I need an umbrella.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Sino-Korean. 필(必 must/certainly) + 요(要 need/essential) + 하다. Polite: 필요해요(하→해). Pattern: noun이/가 필요하다(noun is needed). Common: 도움이 필요하다(need help), 뭐가 필요해요?(what do you need?), 필요한 것(what's needed). Opposite: 불필요하다(unnecessary).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Do you know that person?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 알아요(ㅏ takes 아). Past: 알았어요. ㄹ verb (ㄹ drops before ㄴ,ㅂ,ㅅ: 아는, 압니다, 아세요). Common: 잘 알다(know well), 알겠습니다(I understand, formal), 아는 사람(someone you know). Opposite: 모르다. 알다 vs 알고 있다(knowing as ongoing state).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I don't know much about that.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. 르 irregular: 몰라요(polite, 르→ㄹㄹ). Past: 몰랐어요. Common: 잘 몰라요(I don't really know), 모르겠어요(I'm not sure / I can't tell), 모르는 단어(unknown word). Opposite: 알다(to know). Related: 무지(ignorance), 무식하다(ignorant, can be rude).

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to exist, to have, to be (at a place)
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: Do you have time?
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 있어요. Past: 있었어요. Three core meanings: existence (시간이 있다, there is time), possession (돈이 있다, have money), location (집에 있다, be at home). Honorific: 계시다. Common: 시간 있어요?(do you have time?). Opposite: 없다. One of Korean's most essential verbs.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).english: to not exist, to not have
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I don't have money.
자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).notes: Native Korean. Polite: 없어요. Past: 없었어요. Negation of 있다's three meanings: no existence, no possession, not at location. Honorific: 안 계시다. Common: 돈이 없다(have no money), 시간이 없다(have no time), 관심 없다(not interested). Opposite: 있다.

자주 쓰는 동사 (Common Verbs).example_en: I live in Seoul.
